lessons.title: Hello, World!
lessons.description: The classic first step. Print exactly Hello, World!
lessons.initialCode: # Your code here. Print "Hello, World!"
lessons.fullSolution: print("Hello, World!")
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Hello, World! - The classic first step. Print exactly Hello, World!
  • Basics usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

In Java, the console is a text output window. To print text to it, we use a built-in command from the System library.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

The classic first step in programming. Your goal is to print the exact text "Hello, World!" to the console. Use `System.out.println()` to achieve this.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

The command is System.out.println(). The ln part means "line," so it prints the text and then moves to the next line.

Example:

// This line will print "Welcome to Java!" to the console.
System.out.println("Welcome to Java!");

// This will print a number. Numbers don't need quotes.
System.out.println(123);

For this lesson, you need to print the specific phrase "Hello, World!".

Practical Applications:

Understanding hello, world! is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Best Practices:

  • Write clear, self-documenting code that follows language conventions
  • Add appropriate comments to explain complex logic or important decisions
  • Handle edge cases and error conditions properly
  • Test your code thoroughly with various inputs
  • Follow the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle
  • Consider performance implications for production code

Common Patterns:

When applying hello, world!, you'll commonly see it used in combination with other language features to create robust, maintainable solutions. The fullSolution code demonstrates a practical implementation you can reference.

This pattern is particularly useful when building production applications, solving algorithmic challenges, or creating reusable components. Understanding when and how to apply hello, world! will make you a more effective Java developer.

lessons.title: Variables & Data Types
lessons.description: Create a variable named my_number with value 42 and print it.
lessons.initialCode: # Declare my_number = 42 then print it
lessons.fullSolution:
my_number = 42
print(my_number)
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Variables & Data Types - Create a variable named my_number with value 42 and print it.
  • Basics usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

In Java, a variable is like a labeled box where you can store information. You must first declare it by giving it a data type and a name.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Variables are containers for storing data. Declare an integer variable named `myNumber`, assign it the value `42`, and then print the variable to the console.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • int: for whole numbers (e.g., 5, -10, 42).
  • String: for text (e.g., "Hello, World!").
  • double: for decimal numbers (e.g., 3.14).
  • boolean: for true or false values.

Example:

// 1. Declare a variable 'age' of type 'int'
int age;

// 2. Assign the value 25 to it
age = 25;

// You can also declare and assign in one line (which is common):
int score = 100;

// 3. Print the value stored in the variable (notice no quotes)
System.out.println(score); // This will print 100

In this lesson, create an int variable named myNumber, give it the value 42, and print it.

Understanding variables & data types is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

lessons.description: Update the balance by adding the deposit and subtracting the withdrawal, then print the result.

deposit = 25
withdrawal = 10

# Use arithmetic (+= and -=) to update balance, then print it

deposit = 25
withdrawal = 10

balance -= withdrawal
print(balance)
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Arithmetic & Assignment - Update the balance by adding the deposit and subtracting the withdrawal, then print the result.
  • Basics usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

Use arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /) for calculations. Compound assignment like += and -= updates a variable without rewriting its name.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Update the balance by adding the deposit and subtracting the withdrawal using compound assignment, then print the result.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

int total = 10;
total += 5;  // same as total = total + 5
total -= 2;
total++;    // adds one (same as total += 1)
System.out.println(total);

This shorthand is essential for counters such as i++ that you'll rely on in loops.

lessons.description: Increase the counter to 3 using the ++ operator, then print it. Practice this essential programming concept with hands-on examples.

Key Concepts

  • Comparison Operators - Increase the counter to 3 using the ++ operator, then print it. Practice this essential programming concept with hands-o
  • Basics usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

The increment (++) and decrement (--) operators add or subtract 1. They are shorthand for counter = counter + 1 and counter = counter - 1.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Increase the counter to 3 using the ++ operator, then print it. Practice this essential programming concept with hands-on examples.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

int lives = 3;
lives--;   // now 2
int score = 0;
score++;  // now 1

You'll use i++ constantly when writing loop counters.

lessons.title: For Loops
lessons.description: Use a for loop to print numbers 0 to 4, each on a new line.
lessons.initialCode: # Loop 0..4 with range(5) and print
lessons.fullSolution:
for i in range(5):
    print(i)
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • For Loops - Use a for loop to print numbers 0 to 4, each on a new line.
  • Basics usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

A while loop is used to repeat a block of code as long as a condition is met. It's useful when you don't know exactly how many times you need to loop.

Common Pitfalls

  • Off-by-one errors in loop conditions (< vs <=)
  • Infinite loops from forgetting to update loop counter
  • Modifying loop variable inside the loop body unexpectedly

Overview

A `while` loop executes a block of code as long as a specified condition is true. Create a loop that prints numbers from 1 to 5, each on a new line.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Crucially, you must ensure the condition eventually becomes false, otherwise you'll create an infinite loop!

Example:

int countdown = 3;

while (countdown > 0) {
    System.out.println(countdown);
    countdown--; // This is essential to avoid an infinite loop!
}

System.out.println("Blast off!");

For this lesson, initialize a counter and use a while loop to print numbers 1 through 5. Don't forget to increment your counter inside the loop!

Practical Applications:

Understanding while loops is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

A for loop provides a concise way to write a loop structure. It consists of three parts, separated by semicolons:

Common Pitfalls

  • Off-by-one errors in loop conditions (< vs <=)
  • Infinite loops from forgetting to update loop counter
  • Modifying loop variable inside the loop body unexpectedly

Overview

A `for` loop is ideal when you know exactly how many times you want to loop. Use a for loop to print the numbers from 0 to 4, each on a new line.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  1. Initialization: Executed once at the beginning (e.g., int i = 0).
  2. Condition: Evaluated before each loop iteration. If it's false, the loop stops (e.g., i < 5).
  3. Increment/Decrement: Executed at the end of each iteration (e.g., i++).

Example:

// This loop will print "Iteration 0" through "Iteration 4"
for (int i = 0; i < 5; i++) {
    System.out.println("Iteration " + i);
}

Your task is to create a for loop that prints the value of the counter i on each iteration, from 0 up to (but not including) 5.

Practical Applications:

Understanding for loops is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

An array is a container object that holds a fixed number of values of a single type. The length of an array is established when the array is created.

Common Pitfalls

  • Index out of bounds from not checking size before accessing elements
  • Modifying a list while iterating (ConcurrentModificationException)
  • Using wrong data structure - arrays have fixed size, Lists are dynamic

Overview

An array is a collection of similar types of data. Create an array of integers, store some numbers in it, and then print the second element from the array.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Array elements are accessed by their index, which starts at 0. So, the first element is at index 0, the second at index 1, and so on.

Example:

// Declare and initialize an array of Strings
String[] fruits = {"Apple", "Banana", "Cherry"};

// Access and print the first element (index 0)
System.out.println(fruits[0]); // Prints "Apple"

// Access and print the third element (index 2)
System.out.println(fruits[2]); // Prints "Cherry"

Your task is to create an integer array and print the element at index 1, which is the second value in the list.

A class is a template for creating objects. It defines an object's properties (fields) and behaviors (methods).

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Java is an Object-Oriented language. A `class` is a blueprint for creating `objects`. Create a simple `Dog` class with a `bark()` method, then create an object of that class and call its method.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

An object is an instance of a class. You can create many objects from a single class blueprint.

Example:

// The blueprint for a Car
class Car {
    // A behavior (method) of the Car
    public void startEngine() {
        System.out.println("Engine started!");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // Create an object (an instance) from the Car class
        Car myCar = new Car();
        
        // Call a method on the object
        myCar.startEngine(); // Prints "Engine started!"
    }
}

Practical Applications:

Understanding intro to classes & objects is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

lessons.description: Given x = 7, print Odd if x is odd, otherwise Even.
lessons.initialCode:

# print Even or Odd
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • If / Else - Given x = 7, print Odd if x is odd, otherwise Even.

The if-else if-else statement is perfect for when you have multiple conditions to check in sequence. Java checks them from top to bottom and runs the code for the first one that is true.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Check multiple conditions using `if`, `else if`, and `else`. Based on the `score` variable, print 'Excellent' for scores > 90, 'Good' for scores > 75, and 'Needs Improvement' for all others.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

int number = 0;

if (number > 0) {
    System.out.println("The number is positive.");
} else if (number < 0) {
    System.out.println("The number is negative.");
} else {
    System.out.println("The number is zero.");
}

Notice how only one of the blocks can ever run. The final else is a catch-all if none of the previous conditions were met.

Practical Applications:

Understanding advanced conditionals (else if) is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Best Practices:

  • Add appropriate comments to explain complex logic or important decisions

  • Test your code thoroughly with various inputs
  • Follow the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle
  • Consider performance implications for production code

Overview

Decide a student outcome using if/else-if/else and the && operator. Score >= 90 prints "Honors"; score >= 75 with bonus prints "Pass"; everything else prints "Retake".

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

int age = 17;

if (age >= 18) {
    System.out.println("Full License");
} else if (age >= 16 && hasPermit) {
    System.out.println("Learner Permit");
} else {

}

Logical operators let you create more complex conditions:

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Combine conditions using logical operators. Use the `&&` (AND) operator to check if a user is both `loggedIn` and an `isAdmin`. To pass, change `isAdmin` to `true` and print 'Admin Access Granted'.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • && (AND): True only if both conditions are true.
  • || (OR): True if at least one condition is true.
  • ! (NOT): Inverts the boolean value (true becomes false, false becomes true).

Example:

int age = 25;

Methods (also called functions in other languages) help you organize code and avoid repetition. You define it once and can call it many times.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Write a reusable block of code called a method. Create a method named `greetUser` that takes a `String` name as a parameter and prints 'Hello, [name]!'. Call this method from `main` with your own name.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

A method signature has a few parts: visibility (public), other modifiers (static), return type (void if it returns nothing), the method name, and parameters in parentheses.

Example:

public class Main {

    // A method that takes two integers and prints their sum
    public static void add(int a, int b) {
        System.out.println(a + b);
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // Call the add method with different arguments
        add(5, 3);   // Prints 8
        add(10, 20); // Prints 30
    }
}

So far, our methods have used void, meaning they don't return any information. By changing void to a data type (like int or String), we can make the method send a value back to where it was called.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Methods can compute and return a value. Create a method `add` that takes two integers, returns their sum, and then print the returned result from the `main` method.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

The return keyword is used to specify what value to send back. When return is executed, the method stops immediately.

Example:

public class Main {

    // This method takes a number and returns that number doubled.
    public static int doubleValue(int number) {
        return number * 2;
    }

    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // We call the method and store its return value in a variable.
        int answer = doubleValue(5);

        // Now we can use the result.
        System.out.println(answer); // Prints 10
    }
}

Your task is to create an add method that returns the sum of two numbers.

In Java, the + operator does double duty. When used with numbers, it performs addition. When used with strings, it performs concatenation, which means it joins them together.

Common Pitfalls

  • Assuming strings are mutable (they're immutable - create new instances)

Overview

Combine strings using the `+` operator. Create two string variables and combine them with a space in between to form a sentence, then print the result.

String user = "Alex";

// We can combine strings and other data types.
// Java automatically converts the number 'level' to a string.
String message = "Welcome, " + user + "! You are on level " + level + ".";

System.out.println(message); // Prints "Welcome, Alex! You are on level 5."

A constructor in Java is a special method used to initialize objects. It is called at the time of object creation. It must have the same name as the class and does not have a return type.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

A constructor is a special method that is called when an object is created. Add a constructor to the `Car` class that accepts a `String` for the car's color and prints a message.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Constructors are great for setting up the initial state of an object.

Example:

class Dog {
    String name;

    // This is the constructor for the Dog class.
    public Dog(String dogName) {
        // 'this.name' refers to the instance variable.
        // 'dogName' refers to the parameter.
        this.name = dogName;
        System.out.println("Dog created with name: " + this.name);
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // The constructor is called when we use 'new'.
        Dog myDog = new Dog("Fido"); // Prints "Dog created with name: Fido"
    }
}

The enhanced for loop (or for-each loop) is a more readable and concise way to iterate through all the elements of an array or collection, without needing an index variable (like i).

Common Pitfalls

  • Off-by-one errors in loop conditions (< vs <=)
  • Infinite loops from forgetting to update loop counter

Overview

Java provides a simpler `for-each` loop to iterate over arrays or collections. Use an enhanced for loop to print each fruit from the `fruits` array.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

The syntax is for (Type variableName : arrayName). In each iteration, the loop automatically assigns the next element from the array to your variable.

Example:

int[] numbers = {10, 20, 30};

// For each 'number' of type 'int' in the 'numbers' array...
for (int number : numbers) {
    // ...print it out.
    System.out.println(number);
}

This is often preferred over a standard for loop when you just need to access each element in order and don't need the index.

To get input from a user in the console, Java provides the Scanner class. It's part of Java's utility library, so you must first import it at the top of your file with import java.util.Scanner;.

import java.util.Scanner;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Scanner myScanner = new Scanner(System.in);
        System.out.println("What is your name?");

        // The program will pause here and wait for the user to type.
        String name = myScanner.nextLine(); 

        System.out.println("Nice to meet you, " + name);
    }
}

For this lesson, the simulator will automatically type "World" for you. Your job is to read that input using scanner.nextLine() and use it to construct the final output.

The switch statement is a cleaner alternative to a long chain of if-else if-else statements when you need to compare one variable against several possible constant values.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Use a `switch` statement to handle different cases for a character variable. Based on the `grade`, set the `comment` variable to the correct string.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

The break keyword is crucial. If you forget it, the code will "fall through" and execute the code in the next case as well, which is usually not what you want.

Example:

int day = 4;
String dayString;

switch (day) {
    case 1:  dayString = "Monday";
             break;
    case 2:  dayString = "Tuesday";
             break;
    case 3:  dayString = "Wednesday";
             break;
    // ... and so on
    default: dayString = "Invalid day";
             break;
}
System.out.println(dayString); // Prints "Wednesday" if day was 3

Your task is to build a switch statement for the character variable grade. Note that you need to declare the comment variable before the switch, but you will assign its value inside the different cases.

To find the maximum value in an array, you need a variable to keep track of the largest number found so far. A good strategy is to initialize this variable with the very first value from the array.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Iterate through an array to find the largest value. This is a classic algorithm that combines loops and conditional logic.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Then, you loop through the rest of the array. For each number, you compare it to your "max so far" variable. If the current number is larger, you update your max variable with the current number's value. By the end of the loop, your variable will hold the largest value in the entire array.

Example:

int[] temps = {72, 85, 68, 91, 78};
int highestTemp = temps[0]; // Start with 72

for (int temp : temps) {
    if (temp > highestTemp) {
        highestTemp = temp; // Update if we find a warmer day
    }
}

System.out.println(highestTemp); // Prints 91

Understanding finding the maximum value is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Calculating an average involves two steps: finding the sum of all elements, and then dividing by the number of elements.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Calculate the average of a list of numbers. This requires summing the elements and then performing floating-point division.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

A key concept in Java is integer division versus floating-point (double) division. If you divide an integer by an integer, Java will truncate the result (e.g., 5 / 2 is 2). To get a precise decimal answer, at least one of the numbers in the division must be a double. We can do this by making our sum variable a double from the start.

Example:

int a = 7;
int b = 2;
System.out.println(a / b); // Prints 3 (integer division)

double c = 7.0;
System.out.println(c / b); // Prints 3.5 (floating-point division)

Practical Applications:

Understanding finding the average is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Inheritance is a core principle of Object-Oriented Programming. It allows us to create a new class that is a modified version of an existing class. The new class (the subclass) inherits the fields and methods of the existing class (the superclass).

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Inheritance allows a new class (subclass) to inherit properties and methods from an existing class (superclass). Create a `Dog` class that inherits from `Animal`.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

We use the extends keyword to do this. This promotes code reuse and creates a logical hierarchy.

Example:

// Superclass
class Vehicle {
    public void drive() {
        System.out.println("Driving a vehicle.");
    }
}

// Subclass
class Car extends Vehicle {
    public void honk() {
        System.out.println("Beep beep!");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Car myCar = new Car();
        myCar.drive(); // Inherited from Vehicle
        myCar.honk();  // Defined in Car
    }
}

Practical Applications:

Understanding inheritance (extends) is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Polymorphism means "many forms". In Java, it means you can perform a single action in different ways. A common way to use it is when a superclass reference variable is used to refer to a subclass object.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Polymorphism allows objects of different classes to be treated as objects of a common superclass. This is often achieved by overriding methods.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Method overriding is when a subclass provides a specific implementation for a method that is already defined in its superclass. The @Override annotation is used to indicate this; it's not required but is good practice as it helps the compiler catch errors.

Example:

class Shape {
    public void draw() {
        System.out.println("Drawing a shape");
    }
}

class Circle extends Shape {
    @Override
    public void draw() {
        System.out.println("Drawing a circle");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Shape myShape = new Circle(); // Polymorphism!
        myShape.draw(); // Calls the Circle's draw() method
    }
}

Practical Applications:

Understanding polymorphism & overriding is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Best Practices:

While arrays are useful, their size is fixed once created. The ArrayList class provides a way to have a dynamic, resizable list of objects.

Common Pitfalls

  • Index out of bounds from not checking size before accessing elements
  • Modifying a list while iterating (ConcurrentModificationException)
  • Using wrong data structure - arrays have fixed size, Lists are dynamic

Overview

An `ArrayList` is a resizable array, part of the Java Collections Framework. It's more flexible than a standard array.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

You must import it from java.util.ArrayList. Here are some common methods:

  • add(element): Adds an element to the end of the list.
  • get(index): Returns the element at the specified index.
  • size(): Returns the number of elements in the list.
  • remove(index): Removes the element at the specified index.
  • set(index, element): Replaces the element at the specified index with a new one.

ArrayList is a resizable list. Use add() to append and get() to access by index.

Example:

java.util.List list = new java.util.ArrayList<>();
list.add(1); list.add(2); list.add(3);
System.out.println(list);

An interface is like a blueprint for a class. It can only contain abstract methods (methods without a body) and constants. A class can implement one or more interfaces.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not implementing all required methods from interface
  • Violating method contracts when overriding
  • Making interfaces too broad (prefer focused, single-purpose interfaces)

Overview

An interface is a completely abstract type that is used to group related methods with empty bodies. A class can `implement` an interface, promising to provide the code for its methods.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

This is Java's way of achieving full abstraction and is a key part of designing large, flexible applications. It defines a "contract" that a class must follow if it implements the interface.

Example:

interface Drivable {
    public void startEngine();
}

class Car implements Drivable {
    public void startEngine() {
        System.out.println("Car engine started.");
    }
}

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Car myCar = new Car();
        myCar.startEngine();
    }
}

Practical Applications:

An exception is an event that disrupts the normal flow of a program. Java's exception handling mechanism allows you to manage these errors without crashing the application.

Common Pitfalls

  • Catching broad Exception types instead of specific exceptions
  • Swallowing exceptions without logging or rethrowing
  • Not cleaning up resources in finally blocks (use try-with-resources instead)

Overview

Robust programs must handle potential errors gracefully. Use a `try-catch` block to prevent a crash when trying to divide by zero.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

The try block contains the code that might throw an exception. The catch block contains the code that is executed if an exception of a specific type occurs in the try block.

Example:

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        int[] numbers = {1, 2, 3};
        try {
            // This line will cause an ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException
            System.out.println(numbers[10]);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            // This block runs instead of the program crashing
            System.out.println("Something went wrong.");
        }
    }
}

Practical Applications:

Understanding exception handling (try-catch) is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Best Practices:

  • Write clear, self-documenting code that follows language conventions
  • Add appropriate comments to explain complex logic or important decisions
  • Handle edge cases and error conditions properly
  • Test your code thoroughly with various inputs
  • Follow the DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) principle
  • Consider performance implications for production code

Common Patterns:

When applying exception handling (try-catch), you'll commonly see it used in combination with other language features to create robust, maintainable solutions. The fullSolution code demonstrates a practical implementation you can reference.

When to Use:

This pattern is particularly useful when building production applications, solving algorithmic challenges, or creating reusable components. Understanding when and how to apply exception handling (try-catch) will make you a more effective Java developer.

Key Takeaways:

  • Master the fundamental syntax and structure
  • Understand the practical use cases and applications
  • Know when to apply this pattern vs. alternatives
  • Build on this foundation for more advanced concepts
  • Practice with variations to deepen understanding

Further Learning:

As you become comfortable with exception handling (try-catch), explore related concepts and more complex scenarios. The skills you develop here form the foundation for advanced Java programming techniques.

A HashMap is a powerful data structure for storing key-value pairs, similar to a dictionary. Each value is associated with a unique key. It's incredibly fast for looking up values when you know the key.

Common Pitfalls

  • Trying to reuse a stream after it's been consumed - streams are single-use
  • Using side effects in stream operations (modifying external state)
  • Not handling empty streams properly - check with findFirst().orElse()

Overview

A `HashMap` stores items in "key/value" pairs. Create a HashMap to store capital cities, add a few pairs, and then retrieve a value using its key.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Like ArrayList, you must import it from java.util.HashMap. Common methods include:

  • put(key, value): Adds a key-value pair.
  • get(key): Returns the value associated with the key.
  • remove(key): Removes the key-value pair.
  • size(): Returns the number of pairs.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Strings in Java are objects, and they come with many built-in methods for common operations.

Common Pitfalls

  • Using + for string concatenation in loops (use StringBuilder)
  • Assuming strings are mutable (they're immutable - create new instances)
  • Not handling empty strings or whitespace properly

Overview

The `String` class has many useful methods. Use `length()`, `toUpperCase()`, and `substring()` to manipulate a string and print the results.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • length(): Returns the number of characters in the string.
  • toUpperCase() / toLowerCase(): Returns a new string in the specified case.
  • substring(startIndex): Returns a new string from the start index to the end.
  • substring(startIndex, endIndex): Returns a new string from the start index up to (but not including) the end index.

Example:

String greeting = "Welcome!";
System.out.println(greeting.length()); // Prints 8
System.out.println(greeting.substring(0, 3)); // Prints "Wel"

Understanding string methods is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Every time you use the + operator to concatenate strings, Java creates a new string object in memory. This can be inefficient if you do it many times in a loop. StringBuilder is a mutable object that allows you to modify a sequence of characters without creating new objects for each change.

Common Pitfalls

  • Using + for string concatenation in loops (use StringBuilder)
  • Assuming strings are mutable (they're immutable - create new instances)
  • Not handling empty strings or whitespace properly

Overview

When you need to build a string by appending many parts, `StringBuilder` is more efficient than regular string concatenation. Use it to build a sentence.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Use append() to add to the string. When you are finished, call toString() to get the final String object.

String methods like toLowerCase(), toUpperCase(), and length() return transformed information; Strings are immutable.

System.out.println(s.length());

Method overloading allows you to define multiple methods with the same name in the same class, as long as they have different parameters. Create two `add` methods: one for integers and one for doubles.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Java determines which version of the method to call based on the arguments you provide.

display("Hello"); // Calls the second method

An abstract class is a restricted class that cannot be used to create objects. It serves as a base for subclasses. It can have both abstract and non-abstract (regular) methods.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not implementing all required methods from interface
  • Violating method contracts when overriding
  • Making interfaces too broad (prefer focused, single-purpose interfaces)

Overview

An abstract class cannot be instantiated and can contain abstract methods (without a body). Create an abstract `Shape` class and a `Circle` subclass that implements its abstract method.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

An abstract method is a method that is declared without an implementation. Any subclass of an abstract class must either implement all of the superclass's abstract methods or be declared abstract itself.

This provides a middle ground between a regular class and an interface.

Type casting is used to convert variables from one data type to another.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Type casting is when you assign a value of one primitive data type to another type. Perform both widening (automatic) and narrowing (manual) casting.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • Widening Casting: Happens automatically when passing a smaller size type to a larger size type (e.g., int to double). This is safe as there is no data loss.
  • Narrowing Casting: Must be done manually by placing the type in parentheses in front of the value (e.g., (int)). This can lead to data loss, as you are fitting a larger type into a smaller one. For example, casting a double to an int will truncate the decimal part.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

The ternary operator provides a concise way to write simple conditional assignments. Its syntax is:

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

The ternary operator is a shorthand for an if-else statement. Use it to assign a value to the `result` string based on a condition.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

variable = (condition) ? valueIfTrue : valueIfFalse;

Example:

// Using if-else
int x = 10;
String message;
if (x > 5) {
    message = "x is greater than 5";
} else {
    message = "x is not greater than 5";
}

// Using ternary operator (equivalent)
String message2 = (x > 5) ? "x is greater than 5" : "x is not greater than 5";

Practical Applications:

Understanding ternary operator is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

The do-while loop is similar to a while loop, but with one key difference: the condition is checked after the loop body is executed. This guarantees that the loop will run at least once, regardless of whether the condition is true or false.

Common Pitfalls

  • Off-by-one errors in loop conditions (< vs <=)
  • Infinite loops from forgetting to update loop counter
  • Modifying loop variable inside the loop body unexpectedly

Overview

A `do-while` loop is a variant of the while loop which executes the code block once before checking the condition. Use it to print a countdown that includes 0.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

int count = 5;

do {
    System.out.println("This will print at least once.");
} while (count < 3); // Condition is false, but loop ran once.

Understanding do-while loop is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Java has two categories of data types: primitive types and reference types (objects). Sometimes you need to treat a primitive like an object, for example, when using it with collections like ArrayList. Wrapper classes solve this problem.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Wrapper classes provide a way to use primitive data types (like `int`) as objects. Create an `Integer` object and use one of its methods.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Each primitive has a corresponding wrapper class:

  • int -> Integer
  • double -> Double
  • char -> Character
  • boolean -> Boolean

The process of converting a primitive to a wrapper object is called autoboxing, and the reverse is called unboxing. Java often does this automatically for you.

Classes bundle data and behavior. Create an instance with new and call its methods.

Example:

class Dog {
  void bark() { System.out.println("Woof!"); }
}
new Dog().bark();

Recursion is a powerful but tricky concept where a method calls itself to solve a problem. It breaks a complex problem into smaller, identical subproblems.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Recursion is the technique of making a function call itself. Create a recursive function to calculate the sum of all numbers up to n.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Every recursive function must have two parts:

  1. A base case: A condition that stops the recursion. Without it, you'll get an infinite loop and a StackOverflowError.
  2. A recursive step: The part of the function that calls itself, usually with a modified argument that brings it closer to the base case.

For this problem, summing numbers up to 5 (5+4+3+2+1) can be thought of as 5 + sum(4), and sum(4) is 4 + sum(3), and so on, until you reach the base case of sum(0).

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

System.out.println("Hello, Java!");

A 2D array is an array where each element is itself another array. It's useful for representing data in a grid-like structure, such as a tic-tac-toe board or a spreadsheet.

Common Pitfalls

  • Index out of bounds from not checking size before accessing elements
  • Modifying a list while iterating (ConcurrentModificationException)
  • Using wrong data structure - arrays have fixed size, Lists are dynamic

Overview

A 2D array is like a grid or a table, an array of arrays. Create a 2D array and access an element from a specific row and column.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

You declare it with two sets of square brackets (e.g., int[][]). To access an element, you provide two indices: the first for the row and the second for the column.

Example:

String[][] board = {
    {"X", "O", "X"},
    {"O", "X", "O"},
    {"X", "O", "X"}
};

// Access the middle element (row 1, column 1)
System.out.println(board[1][1]); // Prints "X"

To process every element in a 2D array, a common pattern is to use a "nested loop" â€” a loop inside another loop.

Common Pitfalls

  • Index out of bounds from not checking size before accessing elements
  • Modifying a list while iterating (ConcurrentModificationException)
  • Using wrong data structure - arrays have fixed size, Lists are dynamic

Overview

To iterate over all elements in a 2D array, you need nested loops: one for the rows and one for the columns.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

The outer loop iterates through each of the main arrays (the rows). The inner loop then iterates through all the elements within that specific row-array (the columns).

Example with for-each loops:

String[][] data = {{"A", "B"}, {"C", "D"}};

for (String[] row : data) {
    for (String element : row) {
        System.out.print(element + " "); // Prints "A B C D "
    }
}

Overview

The `final` keyword is used to make a variable a constant, meaning its value cannot be changed. Try to change a final variable to see the error, then fix it by removing the attempt to change it.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • final variable: Creates a constant. Its value cannot be changed after it has been assigned. By convention, constant names are written in all uppercase letters.
  • final method: Cannot be overridden by a subclass.
  • final class: Cannot be extended (inherited from) by another class.

This lesson focuses on final variables. Attempting to reassign a final variable will result in a compile-time error.

Java has four access modifiers:

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions

Overview

Access modifiers control the visibility of classes, fields, and methods. Use the `private` keyword to encapsulate data and provide public getter/setter methods.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • public: The code is accessible for all classes.
  • private: The code is only accessible within the declared class.
  • protected: The code is accessible in the same package and subclasses.
  • default (no keyword): The code is only accessible in the same package.

The private modifier is central to the concept of encapsulation. It hides sensitive data from the outside world. To access or modify private data, you provide public "getter" and "setter" methods.

While break exits a loop entirely, continue just skips the current iteration. When the continue statement is executed, the program immediately jumps to the loop's next iteration, bypassing any remaining code in the current iteration.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

The `continue` statement breaks one iteration (in the loop), if a specified condition occurs, and continues with the next iteration in the loop. Use it to print only the odd numbers.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

// Don't print the number 5
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    if (i == 5) {
        continue; // Skip the rest of the loop body when i is 5
    }
    System.out.println(i);
}

In this lesson, you'll use the modulo operator (%) to check for even numbers and skip them with continue.

There are several ways to loop through a HashMap:

Common Pitfalls

  • Trying to reuse a stream after it's been consumed - streams are single-use
  • Using side effects in stream operations (modifying external state)
  • Not handling empty streams properly - check with findFirst().orElse()

Overview

You can loop through the keys, values, or key-value pairs of a HashMap. Use a for-each loop to print all the keys in the map.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • keySet(): Returns a set of all the keys. You can iterate through this set and use get() to retrieve each value.
  • values(): Returns a collection of all the values. Use this if you don't need the keys.
  • entrySet(): Returns a set of all key-value pairs (as Map.Entry objects). This is the most efficient method if you need both the key and the value in each iteration.

Example using entrySet():

for (Map.Entry entry : capitalCities.entrySet()) {
    System.out.println("Key: " + entry.getKey() + ", Value: " + entry.getValue());
}

lessons.title: Parse requirements.txt
lessons.description: Extract package names from a requirements.txt-style string, ignoring blanks and comments, then print them sorted and comma-separated.
lessons.initialCode:
text = """
# Example requirements
requests==2.31.0
# comment line
flask>=2.0

"""

# Collect package names (strip version specifiers) and print comma-separated in sorted order
lessons.fullSolution:
text = """
# Example requirements
requests==2.31.0
# comment line
flask>=2.0

"""

packages = []
for line in text.splitlines():
    line = line.strip()
    if not line or line.startswith('#'):
        continue
    for sep in ('==', '>=', '<=', '~=', '>', '<'):
        if sep in line:
            line = line.split(sep, 1)[0]
            break
    packages.append(line)
print(", ".join(sorted(packages)))
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Parse requirements.txt - Extract package names from a requirements.txt-style string, ignoring blanks and comments, then print them sorted and com
  • Basics usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Functions usage demonstrated through practical examples

The this keyword is a reference to the current object â€” the object whose method or constructor is being called. It can be used to:

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

The `this` keyword refers to the current object instance. It is commonly used to resolve ambiguity between instance variables and parameters.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  • Disambiguate between instance variables and parameters when they have the same name (the most common use).
  • Call another constructor in the same class (e.g., this(arguments)).
  • Pass the current object as an argument in a method call.

When a parameter has the same name as an instance variable, the parameter "shadows" the instance variable. Using this.variableName ensures you are referring to the instance variable.

Practice the concept using a short example below.

Example:

This is a very common point of confusion for new Java programmers. For primitive types (like int, boolean), the == operator works as expected, comparing their values.

Common Pitfalls

  • Using + for string concatenation in loops (use StringBuilder)
  • Assuming strings are mutable (they're immutable - create new instances)
  • Not handling empty strings or whitespace properly

Overview

When comparing strings for equality, you should use the `.equals()` method, not the `==` operator. The `==` operator checks if two references point to the same object, while `.equals()` checks if the string contents are the same.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

However, for objects (like String), == checks if the two variables refer to the exact same object in memory. The .equals() method, on the other hand, is defined in the class to provide a meaningful comparison of the objects' actual contents.

Rule of thumb: Always use .equals() to compare strings for equality.

String methods like toLowerCase(), toUpperCase(), and length() return transformed information; Strings are immutable.

Example:

String s = "Java";
System.out.println(s.toLowerCase());
System.out.println(s.toUpperCase());
System.out.println(s.length());

The try-catch-finally structure provides robust error handling. The flow is as follows:

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

The `finally` block in a try-catch statement always executes, regardless of whether an exception was thrown or not. It is used to run important cleanup code.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

  1. The try block is executed.
  2. If an exception occurs, the corresponding catch block is executed.
  3. The finally block is always executed, whether an exception happened or not. This makes it the perfect place for cleanup code, like closing files or network connections, to ensure resources are released properly.

lessons.title: Git Conflict Resolution Practice
lessons.description: Filter even numbers from 0..6 and print them. Filter stream elements using predicates to select specific items.
lessons.initialCode:
source = 'feature/landing'
target = 'main'
conflicted_files = ['templates/home.html', 'static/site.css']

# Print commands: checkout target, merge source, edit each conflicted file placeholder, then continue the merge
lessons.fullSolution:
source = 'feature/landing'
target = 'main'
conflicted_files = ['templates/home.html', 'static/site.css']

print(f'git checkout {target}')
print(f'git merge {source}')
for path in conflicted_files:
    print(f'# resolve conflicts in {path}')
print('git add ' + ' '.join(conflicted_files))
print('git commit --no-edit')
lessons.expectedOutput:
git checkout main
git merge feature/landing
# resolve conflicts in templates/home.html
# resolve conflicts in static/site.css
git add templates/home.html static/site.css

lessons.initialCode:

commits = ['feat-a1', 'fix-a2']

lessons.fullSolution:
target_branch = 'release/1.2'
commits = ['feat-a1', 'fix-a2']

print('git log --oneline -5')

lessons.title: groupby Counts
lessons.description: Use reduce to sum numbers. Aggregate stream elements into a single result using the reduce operation.
lessons.initialCode:
import itertools
words=['ant','ape','bat']
# Print a:2 then b:1 (group by first letter)
lessons.fullSolution:
import itertools
words=['ant','ape','bat']
for key, grp in itertools.groupby(sorted(words, key=lambda w: w[0]), key=lambda w: w[0]):
    count = sum(1 for _ in grp)
    print(f'{key}:{count}')
lessons.tutorial:

  • Not handling empty streams properly - check with findFirst().orElse()

Example:

int sum = List.of(1, 2, 3).stream().reduce(0, (a, b) -> a + b);
System.out.println(sum); // 6

}

System.out.println(u1.compareTo(u2) > 0); // true

lessons.title: CSV write/read
lessons.description: Use Pattern/Matcher to find digits in a string. Use regular expressions for powerful text pattern matching and manipulation.
lessons.initialCode:
import csv
# Write rows ['x','y'] and ['1','2'] to data.csv, read and print 2
lessons.fullSolution:
import csv
with open('data.csv','w', newline='') as f:
    w = csv.writer(f)
    w.writerow(['x','y'])
    w.writerow(['1','2'])
with open('data.csv') as f:
    r = csv.reader(f)
    header = next(r)
    row = next(r)
    print(row[1])
lessons.tutorial:

The `Matcher` class finds matches for a regular expression pattern in a string. The `find()` method scans the input sequence to find the next subsequence that matches the pattern.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not escaping special regex characters (. * + ? etc.)
  • Creating new Pattern objects repeatedly (compile once, reuse)
  • Not considering performance with complex regex on large inputs

Overview

Use Pattern/Matcher to find digits in a string. Use regular expressions for powerful text pattern matching and manipulation.

This foundational lesson introduces key programming concepts that form the basis of software development.

Example:

import java.util.regex.*;
Matcher m = Pattern.compile("\\d+").matcher("a12b34c");
while (m.find()) { System.out.println(m.group()); } // 12, 34

`flatMap` transforms each element of a stream into another stream and then concatenates these streams into a single, "flattened" stream.

Common Pitfalls

  • Trying to reuse a stream after it's been consumed - streams are single-use
  • Using side effects in stream operations (modifying external state)
  • Not handling empty streams properly - check with findFirst().orElse()

Overview

Flatten a list of lists and print each element. Store and retrieve key-value pairs efficiently using hash-based data structures.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.stream.*;
import java.util.List;
List> listOfLists = List.of(List.of(1), List.of(2, 3));
listOfLists.stream().flatMap(List::stream).forEach(System.out::println); // 1, 2, 3

lessons.title: threading + Lock
lessons.description: Use Map.compute to count character frequency preserving first-seen order. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
import threading
# Start two threads appending 1 and 2 (with a lock) then print the sum 3
lessons.fullSolution:
import threading
lock = threading.Lock()
vals = []

def add(v):
    with lock:
        vals.append(v)

t1 = threading.Thread(target=add, args=(1,))
t2 = threading.Thread(target=add, args=(2,))
t1.start(); t2.start(); t1.join(); t2.join()
print(sum(vals))
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • threading + Lock - Use Map.compute to count character frequency preserving first-seen order. Intermediate concept building on fundamental p

lessons.title: ThreadPoolExecutor
lessons.description: Partition numbers into even/odd and print counts. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor
# Submit squares 1..3 and print results 1,4,9 on new lines
lessons.fullSolution:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor
with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=3) as ex:
    futs = [ex.submit(lambda x: x*x, i) for i in (1,2,3)]
    for f in futs:
        print(f.result())
lessons.tutorial:

lessons.title: asyncio.gather
lessons.description: Repeat a string and print it. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio
# Define async f(x)->2*x; gather for 1,2,3 and print results
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio
async def f(x):
    return 2*x
async def main():
    res = await asyncio.gather(f(1), f(2), f(3))
    for v in res:
        print(v)
asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:

lessons.title: CompletableFuture.thenCombine (Sum)
lessons.description: Combine two async computations and print their sum. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Define async def square(x): return x*x
# Use asyncio.gather over [1,2,3] and print the sum of results
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def square(x):
    return x*x

async def main():
    results = await asyncio.gather(*(square(x) for x in [1,2,3]))
    print(sum(results))

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolutionCommented:
import asyncio

# Define an async function. It returns immediately with a coroutine when called.
async def square(x):
    return x * x

async def main():
    # Schedule the coroutines concurrently and wait for all to finish.
    coros = [square(x) for x in [1, 2, 3]]
    results = await asyncio.gather(*coros)
    print(sum(results))  # 14

# Drive the event loop.
asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • CompletableFuture.thenCombine - Combine two async computations and print their sum. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-b
  • Async usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

lessons.initialCode:
import contextlib

# Create a context manager that prints 'enter' on enter and 'exit' on exit
# Within it, print 'inside'
lessons.fullSolutionCommented:
import contextlib

# Build a context manager with setup/teardown around the 'with' block.
@contextlib.contextmanager
def tag():
    print('enter')  # setup
    try:
        yield       # body runs here
    finally:
        print('exit')  # teardown always runs

with tag():
    print('inside')

lessons.fullSolutionCommented:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor

# Map a function across inputs in a thread pool and aggregate results.
def sq(x):
    return x * x

with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=2) as ex:
    # ex.map returns a generator of results in input order
    total = sum(ex.map(sq, [1, 2, 3, 4]))
    print(total)  # 30

lessons.initialCode:
import csv
import io

data = '''id,price,qty
1,10,2
2,15,1
3,8,5
'''
# Compute total revenue (price*qty) for rows with price >= 10 and print it
lessons.fullSolution:
import csv
import io

data = '''id,price,qty
1,10,2
2,15,1
3,8,5
'''
reader = csv.DictReader(io.StringIO(data))
print(sum(int(r['price'])*int(r['qty']) for r in reader if int(r['price']) >= 10))
lessons.fullSolutionCommented:
import csv
import io

# Parse CSV into dicts, filter rows, and aggregate revenue.
data = '''id,price,qty
1,10,2
2,15,1
3,8,5
'''
reader = csv.DictReader(io.StringIO(data))
revenue = 0
for row in reader:
    price = int(row['price'])
    qty = int(row['qty'])
    if price >= 10:
        revenue += price * qty
print(revenue)  # 35

lessons.title: sqlite3 In-Memory
lessons.description: Group strings by first character and sum their lengths. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
import sqlite3

# Create an in-memory DB, a table nums(v INT), insert 1,2,3
# Query SELECT SUM(v) and print the result
lessons.fullSolution:
import sqlite3

con = sqlite3.connect(':memory:')
cur = con.cursor()
cur.execute('CREATE TABLE nums(v INT)')
cur.executemany('INSERT INTO nums(v) VALUES (?)', [(1,),(2,),(3,)])
cur.execute('SELECT SUM(v) FROM nums')
print(cur.fetchone()[0])
con.close()

lessons.title: Capstone: Log Aggregator
lessons.description: Compute 2^10 mod 1000 using BigInteger. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
import re

logs = '''[INFO] boot
[ERROR] fail A
[WARN] disk
[ERROR] fail B
'''
# Count lines starting with [ERROR] and [WARN] and print 'E:<n> W:<m>'
lessons.fullSolution:
import re

logs = '''[INFO] boot
[ERROR] fail A
[WARN] disk
[ERROR] fail B
'''
E = len(re.findall(r'^\[ERROR\]', logs, flags=re.M))
W = len(re.findall(r'^\[WARN\]', logs, flags=re.M))
print(f'E:{E} W:{W}')

import java.util.*;
import java.util.stream.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        String s = "a b a c b b";
        Map<String, Long> m = Arrays.stream(s.split(" ")).collect(Collectors.groupingBy(x -> x, Collectors.counting()));
        m.entrySet().stream()
            .sorted((e1,e2) -> Long.compare(e2.getValue(), e1.getValue()))
            .limit(2)
            .forEach(e -> System.out.println(e.getKey()+":"+e.getValue()));
    }

lessons.title: Capstone: asyncio Timeout
lessons.description: Use completeOnTimeout to return 'fast' if slow task exceeds 100ms. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Create two coroutines: slow sleeps 1.0s and returns 'slow', fast returns 'fast'
# Use wait_for to get fast within 0.1s and print it
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(1.0)
    return 'slow'

async def fast():
    return 'fast'

async def main():
    print(await asyncio.wait_for(fast(), timeout=0.1))

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Capstone - Use completeOnTimeout to return 'fast' if slow task exceeds 100ms. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableF
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

Bound latency by completing a future with a fallback if it exceeds a deadline.

Common Pitfalls

  • Race conditions from unsynchronized access to shared mutable state
  • Deadlocks from improper lock ordering or circular dependencies
  • Not handling exceptions properly in async operations

Overview

Use completeOnTimeout to return 'fast' if slow task exceeds 100ms. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        CompletableFuture<String> slow = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> {
            try { Thread.sleep(1000); } catch (InterruptedException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); }
            return "slow";
        });
        System.out.println(slow.completeOnTimeout("fast", 100, TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS).join());
    }
}

lessons.title: asyncio.Semaphore
lessons.description: Coordinate two threads and print 'done' after both complete. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Create a Semaphore(2) and run 3 workers that each return 1
# Gather results and print their sum (should be 3)
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def worker(sem):
    async with sem:
        await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
        return 1

async def main():
    sem = asyncio.Semaphore(2)
    results = await asyncio.gather(*(worker(sem) for _ in range(3)))
    print(sum(results))

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • asyncio.Semaphore - Coordinate two threads and print 'done' after both complete. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming sk
  • Collections usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

Use CountDownLatch to wait for a set of operations to complete.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Coordinate two threads and print 'done' after both complete. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        CountDownLatch latch = new CountDownLatch(2);
        Runnable r = () -> { try { Thread.sleep(50); } catch (InterruptedException e) {} finally { latch.countDown(); } };
        new Thread(r).start();
        new Thread(r).start();
        latch.await();
        System.out.println("done");
    }
}

lessons.title: as_completed (futures)
lessons.description: Bound parallelism with a Semaphore and count completions. Implement concurrent programming with threads for parallel task execution.
lessons.initialCode:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed

# Submit squares for 1..4 and sum results using as_completed, then print the sum (30)
lessons.fullSolution:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed

def sq(x):
    return x*x

with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=3) as ex:
    futs = [ex.submit(sq, x) for x in [1,2,3,4]]
    total = 0
    for f in as_completed(futs):
        total += f.result()
    print(total)
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • as_completed - Bound parallelism with a Semaphore and count completions. Implement concurrent programming with threads for parallel tas
  • Algorithms usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Collections usage demonstrated through practical examples

A Semaphore limits how many threads can enter a critical region simultaneously, useful for rate-limiting or resource pools.

Common Pitfalls

  • Trying to reuse a stream after it's been consumed - streams are single-use
  • Using side effects in stream operations (modifying external state)
  • Not handling empty streams properly - check with findFirst().orElse()

Overview

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

ReentrantLock offers explicit locking with try/finally for predictable release; it supports advanced features beyond synchronized.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Protect a shared counter with ReentrantLock across two threads and print 2000. Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.locks.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        Lock lock = new ReentrantLock();
        final int[] counter = {0};
        Runnable inc = () -> {
            for (int i = 0; i < 1000; i++) {
                lock.lock();
                try { counter[0]++; } finally { lock.unlock(); }
            }
        };

Define a sealed Shape, implement Rect and compute its area with pattern matching.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

public class Main {
    sealed interface Shape permits Rect, Circle {}
    static final class Rect implements Shape { int w,h; Rect(int w,int h){ this.w=w; this.h=h; } }
    static final class Circle implements Shape { int r; Circle(int r){ this.r=r; } }
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Shape s = new Rect(3,4);
        if (s instanceof Rect r) {
            System.out.println(r.w * r.h);
        }
    }
}

Key Concepts

flatMapping allows flattening as part of a downstream collector without an explicit pre-flatMap.

Common Pitfalls

  • Trying to reuse a stream after it's been consumed - streams are single-use
  • Using side effects in stream operations (modifying external state)
  • Not handling empty streams properly - check with findFirst().orElse()

Overview

Flatten during collection and sum integers parsed from strings. Use stream collectors to accumulate elements into collections or other data structures.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.*;
import java.util.stream.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List<String> rows = Arrays.asList("1,2", "3");
        int sum = rows.stream().collect(
            Collectors.flatMapping(
                s -> Arrays.stream(s.split(",")).map(Integer::parseInt),
                Collectors.summingInt(Integer::intValue)
            )
        );

Practical Applications:

Understanding collectors.flatmapping is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

Key Concepts

  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

allOf waits for multiple futures; use a continuation to compose their results.

Common Pitfalls

  • Race conditions from unsynchronized access to shared mutable state
  • Deadlocks from improper lock ordering or circular dependencies
  • Not handling exceptions properly in async operations

Overview

Combine two async computations and print their summed result. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        CompletableFuture<Integer> a = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> 1);
        CompletableFuture<Integer> b = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> 2);
        int sum = CompletableFuture.allOf(a, b).thenApply(v -> a.join() + b.join()).join();
        System.out.println(sum);
    }
}

Understanding completablefuture.allof is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

lessons.title: Capstone: CSV + File IO + Sum
lessons.description: Use a named capturing group to extract a word and print it. Use regular expressions for powerful text pattern matching and manipulation.
lessons.initialCode:
import csv

# Create a.csv with rows: name,score then Ada,10 then Bob,20 then Cia,15
# Read it back using csv.DictReader, sum the 'score' as ints, and print the total (45)
lessons.fullSolution:
import csv

with open('a.csv', 'w', newline='') as f:
    w = csv.writer(f)
    w.writerow(['name','score'])
    w.writerow(['Ada','10'])
    w.writerow(['Bob','20'])
    w.writerow(['Cia','15'])

with open('a.csv') as f:
    r = csv.DictReader(f)
    total = sum(int(row['score']) for row in r)
print(total)

lessons.title: ThreadPoolExecutor (sum squares)
lessons.description: Use a thread pool to square 1..3 and print the sum (14).
lessons.initialCode:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor

# Submit tasks that square 1..3 and print the sum (14)
lessons.fullSolution:
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor

with ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=3) as ex:
    futs = [ex.submit(lambda x: x*x, i) for i in (1,2,3)]
    print(sum(f.result() for f in futs))

lessons.title: itertools.groupby (top counts)
lessons.description: Group words and print the top 2 as 'b:3' then 'a:2'.
lessons.initialCode:
from itertools import groupby

# Using s='a b a c b b', group words to count occurrences and print top 2: b:3 then a:2
lessons.fullSolution:
from itertools import groupby

s = 'a b a c b b'
words = sorted(s.split())
counts = [(k, sum(1 for _ in g)) for k, g in groupby(words)]
for k, c in sorted(counts, key=lambda kv: -kv[1])[:2]:
    print(f'{k}:{c}')

lessons.title: asyncio.gather (sum results)
lessons.description: Run 3 async tasks concurrently and print the sum of their results (6).
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Create 3 coroutines returning 1,2,3 after small sleeps; gather and print sum (6)
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def f(v, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    return v

async def main():
    xs = await asyncio.gather(f(1,0.05), f(2,0.05), f(3,0.05))
    print(sum(xs))

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • asyncio.gather - Run 3 async tasks concurrently and print the sum of their results (6).
  • Collections usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

Use ExecutorService.invokeAll to submit a batch of tasks and wait for their results, then reduce them.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Use a fixed thread pool to compute squares of 1..3 in parallel and print their sum (14).

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.*;
import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        ExecutorService es = Executors.newFixedThreadPool(3);
        try {
            List<Callable<Integer>> tasks = Arrays.asList(
                () -> 1*1, () -> 2*2, () -> 3*3
            );
            int sum = 0;
            for (Future<Integer> f : es.invokeAll(tasks)) { sum += f.get(); }

import java.nio.file.*;
import java.io.*;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception {
        Path d = Paths.get("d");
        Files.createDirectories(d);
        Files.writeString(d.resolve("a.txt"), "x");
        Files.writeString(d.resolve("b.md"), "y");
        Files.writeString(d.resolve("c.txt"), "z");
        long c = Files.walk(d).filter(p -> p.toString().endsWith(".txt")).count();

Comparator.comparing composes readable multi-key sorts; combine with thenComparing.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not handling null values in comparison

Overview

Sort Person(name,age) by age then name and print names on separate lines. Implement custom sorting logic by defining comparison methods for objects.

This intermediate lesson builds on fundamental concepts with more sophisticated techniques.

Example:

import java.util.*;

public class Main {
    static class Person { String name; int age; Person(String n,int a){name=n;age=a;} }
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        List<Person> ps = Arrays.asList(new Person("Zoe", 30), new Person("Ada", 30), new Person("Bob", 25));
        ps.sort(Comparator.comparing((Person p) -> p.age).thenComparing(p -> p.name));
        for (Person p : ps) System.out.println(p.name);
    }
}
