lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • CompletableFuture.thenCombine - Combine two async computations (2 and 3) and print their sum (5). Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFu
  • Async usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

thenCombine merges results from two independent futures.

Common Pitfalls

  • Race conditions from unsynchronized access to shared mutable state
  • Deadlocks from improper lock ordering or circular dependencies
  • Not handling exceptions properly in async operations

Overview

Combine two async computations (2 and 3) and print their sum (5). Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.

This advanced lesson explores complex patterns used in professional software development.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    CompletableFuture<Integer> a = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> 2);
    CompletableFuture<Integer> b = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> 3);
    System.out.println(a.thenCombine(b, Integer::sum).join());
  }
}

lessons.title: asyncio.wait_for timeout
lessons.description: Return the first of two futures (fast vs slow) and print 'fast'. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Use asyncio.wait_for on a 0.2s sleep with 0.05s timeout; print 'timeout'
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.2)

try:
    asyncio.run(asyncio.wait_for(slow(), 0.05))
    print('ok')
except asyncio.TimeoutError:
    print('timeout')
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • asyncio.wait_for timeout - Return the first of two futures (fast vs slow) and print 'fast'. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFut
  • Async usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

anyOf completes with the first finished future; use join() to get the result.

Common Pitfalls

  • Race conditions from unsynchronized access to shared mutable state
  • Deadlocks from improper lock ordering or circular dependencies
  • Not handling exceptions properly in async operations

Overview

Return the first of two futures (fast vs slow) and print 'fast'. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.

This advanced lesson explores complex patterns used in professional software development.

Example:

import java.util.concurrent.*;

public class Main {
  static void sleep(long ms) { try { Thread.sleep(ms); } catch (InterruptedException e) { throw new RuntimeException(e); } }
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    CompletableFuture<String> fast = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> { sleep(50); return "fast"; });
    CompletableFuture<String> slow = CompletableFuture.supplyAsync(() -> { sleep(200); return "slow"; });
    System.out.println((String) CompletableFuture.anyOf(fast, slow).join());
  }
}

Practical Applications:

lessons.title: asyncio.Semaphore (limit concurrency)
lessons.description: Use java.util.regex to find the first number in a string. Use regular expressions for powerful text pattern matching and manipulation.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Use an asyncio.Semaphore to limit concurrency to 2 while running 4 tasks.
# Each task should return 1; after gathering, print the sum (4).
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def worker(sema):
    async with sema:
        await asyncio.sleep(0.05)
        return 1

async def main():
    sema = asyncio.Semaphore(2)
    tasks = [asyncio.create_task(worker(sema)) for _ in range(4)]
    results = await asyncio.gather(*tasks)
    print(sum(results))

asyncio.run(main())

lessons.title: asyncio.Queue producer/consumer
lessons.description: Use a ReentrantReadWriteLock to write 42 to a map and then read it; print 42. Store and retrieve key-value pairs efficiently using hash-based data structures.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

# Create an asyncio.Queue. Producer should put 5 items then a sentinel (None).
# Consumer should count items until sentinel, then print the count (5).
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def producer(q):
    for i in range(5):
        await q.put(i)
    await q.put(None)  # sentinel

async def consumer(q):
    count = 0
    while True:
        item = await q.get()
        if item is None:
            print(count)
            return
        count += 1

async def main():
    q = asyncio.Queue()
    await asyncio.gather(producer(q), consumer(q))

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:

lessons.title: CompletableFuture.thenCombine (Greeting)
lessons.description: Create two futures and combine them into a single greeting; print 'Hello Alex'. Implement asynchronous programming using CompletableFuture for non-blocking operations.
lessons.initialCode:
from contextlib import ExitStack

# Open a.txt and b.txt with ExitStack, write 'A' and 'B' respectively.
# Reopen and read both, then print their concatenation (AB).
lessons.fullSolution:
from contextlib import ExitStack

with ExitStack() as stack:
    fa = stack.enter_context(open('a.txt', 'w'))
    fb = stack.enter_context(open('b.txt', 'w'))
    fa.write('A')
    fb.write('B')

with ExitStack() as stack:
    fa = stack.enter_context(open('a.txt'))
    fb = stack.enter_context(open('b.txt'))
    print(fa.read() + fb.read())

lessons.title: setUp/tearDown Cleanup
lessons.description: Use setUp to create a temporary directory and tearDown to remove it, then report the cleanup flag.
lessons.initialCode:
import unittest
import tempfile
import io
from pathlib import Path


CLEANED = False


class MessageWriter:
    def __init__(self, directory: Path):
        self.path = directory / "message.txt"

    def write(self, text: str) -> None:
        self.path.write_text(text, encoding="utf-8")


# Implement a unittest.TestCase that:
#   * creates a TemporaryDirectory and MessageWriter in setUp
#   * writes "hello" and asserts the file contains it in a test method
#   * cleans up the directory in tearDown and sets the CLEANED flag
# Run the suite with TextTestRunner(stream=io.StringIO()) and print "Tests run: X, cleaned: Y".
lessons.fullSolution:
import unittest
import tempfile
import io
from pathlib import Path


CLEANED = False


class MessageWriter:
    def __init__(self, directory: Path):
        self.path = directory / "message.txt"

    def write(self, text: str) -> None:
        self.path.write_text(text, encoding="utf-8")


class MessageWriterTests(unittest.TestCase):
    def setUp(self):
        self.tmp = tempfile.TemporaryDirectory()
        self.directory = Path(self.tmp.name)
        self.writer = MessageWriter(self.directory)

    def tearDown(self):
        global CLEANED
        self.tmp.cleanup()
        CLEANED = not self.directory.exists()

    def test_write_persists_content(self):
        self.writer.write("hello")
        self.assertEqual(
            self.writer.path.read_text(encoding="utf-8"),
            "hello",
        )


suite = unittest.defaultTestLoader.loadTestsFromTestCase(MessageWriterTests)
result = unittest.TextTestRunner(stream=io.StringIO()).run(suite)
print(f"Tests run: {result.testsRun}, cleaned: {CLEANED}")
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • setUp/tearDown Cleanup - Use setUp to create a temporary directory and tearDown to remove it, then report the cleanup flag.
  • Collections usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Math and Stats usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.initialCode:
import unittest
import io
from unittest import mock


def total_order_amount(client) -> int:
    orders = client.fetch_orders()
    return sum(order["total"] for order in orders)


# Build a TestCase that uses a Mock client to:
#   * stub fetch_orders() to return [{"total": 12}, {"total": 8}]
#   * assert total_order_amount returns 20
#   * verify fetch_orders was called exactly once
# Run the suite with TextTestRunner(stream=io.StringIO()) and print "Tests run: X, failures: Y".
lessons.fullSolution:
import unittest
import io
from unittest import mock


def total_order_amount(client) -> int:
    orders = client.fetch_orders()
    return sum(order["total"] for order in orders)


class TotalOrderAmountTests(unittest.TestCase):
    def test_calls_client_and_sums_totals(self):
        client = mock.Mock()
        client.fetch_orders.return_value = [{"total": 12}, {"total": 8}]
        self.assertEqual(total_order_amount(client), 20)
        client.fetch_orders.assert_called_once()


suite = unittest.defaultTestLoader.loadTestsFromTestCase(TotalOrderAmountTests)
result = unittest.TextTestRunner(stream=io.StringIO()).run(suite)
print(f"Tests run: {result.testsRun}, failures: {len(result.failures)}")

]

THRESHOLD = 0.85


# Build an operations summary:
# * Count total suites and failures.
# * Collect coverage alerts for modules below THRESHOLD formatted like "frontend<0.85".
# * Print three lines exactly:
#     Tests run: <total>, failed: <failures>
#     Coverage alerts: <comma-separated alerts or "none">
#     Gate: <ALLOW or BLOCK>
# Gate stays BLOCK if any failures or coverage alerts exist.
lessons.fullSolution:
results = [
    {"name": "unit", "status": "passed", "duration": 58.1},
    {"name": "api", "status": "failed", "duration": 120.4},
    {"name": "smoke", "status": "passed", "duration": 30.0},
]

coverage = {"backend": 0.91, "frontend": 0.82}
THRESHOLD = 0.85

failures = [r for r in results if r["status"] != "passed"]
alerts = [f"{name}<{THRESHOLD:.2f}" for name, value in coverage.items() if value < THRESHOLD]

print(f"Tests run: {len(results)}, failed: {len(failures)}")
if alerts:
    print("Coverage alerts: " + ", ".join(alerts))
else:
    print("Coverage alerts: none")

gate = "BLOCK" if failures or alerts else "ALLOW"
print(f"Gate: {gate}")

Tests run: 3, failed: 1
Coverage alerts: frontend<0.85
Gate: BLOCK

lessons.title: Error Budget Burn Forecast
lessons.description: Calculate consumed error budget, project 30-day burn, and flag the service as healthy or at risk.
lessons.initialCode:
error_budget_minutes = 43.2
downtime_minutes = [12.0, 4.5, 0, 9.3, 5.1]
days_elapsed = 18
PERIOD_DAYS = 30

# Compute the total downtime spent, remaining budget, and projected burn for the full period.
# Print exactly four lines:
# Error budget: <value> min
# Spent: <value> min
# Remaining: <value> min
# Status: <HEALTHY or AT_RISK>
# Values should be rounded to one decimal place using round(value, 1).
# Status is AT_RISK when the projected burn (current average * PERIOD_DAYS) exceeds the budget.
lessons.fullSolution:
error_budget_minutes = 43.2
downtime_minutes = [12.0, 4.5, 0, 9.3, 5.1]
days_elapsed = 18
PERIOD_DAYS = 30

spent = round(sum(downtime_minutes), 1)
remaining = round(error_budget_minutes - spent, 1)
burn_per_day = sum(downtime_minutes) / days_elapsed
projected = burn_per_day * PERIOD_DAYS
status = "AT_RISK" if projected > error_budget_minutes else "HEALTHY"

print(f"Error budget: {round(error_budget_minutes, 1)} min")
print(f"Spent: {spent} min")
print(f"Remaining: {remaining} min")
print(f"Status: {status}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Error budget: 43.2 min
Spent: 30.9 min
Remaining: 12.3 min
Status: AT_RISK

lessons.title: Merge Sort Recursion
lessons.description: Compute the length of the longest increasing subsequence in O(n log n) time. Advanced programming technique for building robust applications.
lessons.initialCode:
def merge_sort(nums):
    # TODO: implement merge sort that returns a new sorted list
    return nums


print(merge_sort([5, 1, 4, 2, 8]))
lessons.fullSolution:
def merge_sort(nums):
    if len(nums) <= 1:
        return nums
    mid = len(nums) // 2
    left = merge_sort(nums[:mid])
    right = merge_sort(nums[mid:])
    merged = []
    i = j = 0
    while i < len(left) and j < len(right):
        if left[i] <= right[j]:
            merged.append(left[i])
            i += 1
        else:
            merged.append(right[j])
            j += 1
    merged.extend(left[i:])
    merged.extend(right[j:])
    return merged


print(merge_sort([5, 1, 4, 2, 8]))
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Merge Sort Recursion - Compute the length of the longest increasing subsequence in O(n log n) time. Advanced programming technique for building

lessons.title: Reverse Singly Linked List
lessons.description: Reverse a singly linked list iteratively and return the new head.
lessons.initialCode:
class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next


def reverse_list(head):
    # TODO: reverse the list iteratively
    return head


head = ListNode(1, ListNode(2, ListNode(3, ListNode(4))))

values = []
while node:
    values.append(node.val)
    node = node.next
print(values)
lessons.fullSolution:
class ListNode:
    def __init__(self, val, next=None):
        self.val = val
        self.next = next


def reverse_list(head):
    prev = None
    current = head
    while current:
        nxt = current.next
        current.next = prev
        prev = current
        current = nxt
    return prev


head = ListNode(1, ListNode(2, ListNode(3, ListNode(4))))
node = reverse_list(head)
values = []
while node:
    values.append(node.val)
    node = node.next
print(values)

  • Caching usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.fullSolution:
from collections import OrderedDict

class LRUCache:
    def __init__(self, capacity):
        self.capacity = capacity
        self.data = OrderedDict()

    def get(self, key):
        if key not in self.data:
            return -1
        value = self.data.pop(key)
        self.data[key] = value
        return value

    def put(self, key, value):
        if key in self.data:
            self.data.pop(key)
        self.data[key] = value
        if len(self.data) > self.capacity:
            self.data.popitem(last=False)


cache = LRUCache(2)
cache.put('user:1', 'alice')
cache.put('user:2', 'bob')
print(cache.get('user:1'))
cache.put('user:3', 'charlie')
print(cache.get('user:2'))
print(cache.get('user:3'))

lessons.title: Capacity Planning Calculator
lessons.description: Compute the server count for peak and average load with redundancy.
lessons.initialCode:
import math

requests_peak = 180_000
requests_avg = 90_000
tps_per_server = 4_500
redundancy_factor = 1.25

# TODO: compute ceil((load / tps_per_server) * redundancy_factor) for peak and average.
# Print exactly:
# Peak servers needed: 50
# Average servers needed: 25
lessons.fullSolution:
import math

requests_peak = 180_000
requests_avg = 90_000
tps_per_server = 4_500
redundancy_factor = 1.25

peak_servers = math.ceil((requests_peak / tps_per_server) * redundancy_factor)
avg_servers = math.ceil((requests_avg / tps_per_server) * redundancy_factor)

print(f"Peak servers needed: {peak_servers}")
print(f"Average servers needed: {avg_servers}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Peak servers needed: 50
Average servers needed: 25

lessons.title: Index Strategy Summary
lessons.description: Summarize the primary, covering, and partial indexes defined for the orders table.
lessons.fullSolution:
table = "orders"
primary = {"name": "orders_pkey", "columns": "id"}
covering = [
    {"name": "idx_orders_state_status", "columns": "state, status"},
    {"name": "idx_orders_customer_created", "columns": "customer_id, created_at DESC"},
]
partial = {"name": "idx_orders_ready", "definition": "WHERE status = 'READY_TO_SHIP'"}

print(f"Index Strategy: {table}")
print(f"Primary key: {primary['name']} ({primary['columns']})")
print("Covering indexes:")
for index in covering:
    print(f"- {index['name']} on ({index['columns']})")
print("Partial index:")
print(f"- {partial['name']} {partial['definition']}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Index Strategy: orders
Primary key: orders_pkey (id)
Covering indexes:
- idx_orders_state_status on (state, status)
- idx_orders_customer_created on (customer_id, created_at DESC)

lessons.title: SQLAlchemy Repository Sketch
lessons.description: Output the key manifest lines for running the service on Kubernetes. Advanced programming technique for building robust applications.
lessons.initialCode:
imports = [
    "from datetime import datetime",
    "from typing import Iterable, Optional",
    "from sqlalchemy import select",
    "from sqlalchemy.orm import Session",
    "from .models import Order",
]
methods = [
    "    def __init__(self, session: Session) -> None:",
    "        self._session = session",
    "",
    "    def get_by_external_id(self, external_id: str) -> Optional[Order]:",
    "        stmt = select(Order).where(Order.external_id == external_id)",
    "        return self._session.scalar(stmt)",
    "",
    "    def list_by_statuses(self, statuses: Iterable[str]) -> list[Order]:",
    "        stmt = select(Order).where(Order.status.in_(list(statuses)))",
    "        return list(self._session.scalars(stmt))",
    "",
    "    def find_stuck_orders(self, cutoff: datetime) -> list[Order]:",
    "        stmt = select(Order).where(Order.created_at < cutoff, Order.status == "PENDING")",
    "        return list(self._session.scalars(stmt))",
]

lessons.title: Error Budget Dashboard Row
lessons.description: Given counts and budget limits, compute the current error rate and how much budget remains, then print the report.
lessons.initialCode:
service = "auth-api"
total_requests = 100000
allowed_error_budget_pct = 2.0
observed_errors = 420

# TODO: calculate the error rate and remaining budget, then print each line of the summary
lessons.fullSolution:
service = "auth-api"
total_requests = 100000
allowed_error_budget_pct = 2.0
observed_errors = 420

error_rate = (observed_errors / total_requests) * 100
budget_remaining = allowed_error_budget_pct - error_rate

print(f"Service: {service}")
print(f"Requests: {total_requests}")
print(f"Errors: {observed_errors}")
print(f"Error Rate: {error_rate:.2f}%")
print(f"Budget Remaining: {budget_remaining:.2f}%")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Service: auth-api
Requests: 100000
Errors: 420
Error Rate: 0.42%
Budget Remaining: 1.58%
lessons.tutorial:

lessons.title: Capacity Forecast Table
lessons.description: Project request-per-second capacity across the next three quarters using the provided growth rates.
lessons.initialCode:
current_rps = 1800
growth_rates = [0.15, 0.22, 0.18]
planning_horizon = ["Q1", "Q2", "Q3"]

# TODO: print a heading then loop through the horizon, compounding growth each step
lessons.fullSolution:
current_rps = 1800
growth_rates = [0.15, 0.22, 0.18]
planning_horizon = ["Q1", "Q2", "Q3"]

print("Capacity Forecast")
projected = current_rps
for period, rate in zip(planning_horizon, growth_rates):
    projected *= 1 + rate
    print(f"{period}: {round(projected)} rps")
lessons.expectedOutput:

Q1: 2070 rps
Q2: 2525 rps
Q3: 2980 rps

StampedLock supports optimistic reads: grab a stamp with tryOptimisticRead() and fall back to a read lock if another writer intervened.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Write 42 under a StampedLock and read it back with an optimistic read fallback. Advanced programming technique for building robust applications.

This advanced lesson explores complex patterns used in professional software development.

Example:

StampedLock lock = new StampedLock();
long stamp = lock.tryOptimisticRead();
if (!lock.validate(stamp)) {
    stamp = lock.readLock();
    lock.unlockRead(stamp);
}

lessons.title: asyncio.wait FIRST_COMPLETED
lessons.description: Race fast and slow tasks, cancel the slower one, and print the first result.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.2)
    return "slow"

async def fast():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.05)
    return "fast"

async def main():
    # TODO: launch both tasks, wait for FIRST_COMPLETED, cancel the slower one, and print the first result
    pass

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.2)
    return "slow"

async def fast():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.05)
    return "fast"

async def main():
    tasks = {asyncio.create_task(slow()), asyncio.create_task(fast())}
    done, pending = await asyncio.wait(tasks, return_when=asyncio.FIRST_COMPLETED)
    for task in pending:
        task.cancel()
    if pending:
        await asyncio.gather(*pending, return_exceptions=True)
    first = next(iter(done))
    print(first.result())

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • asyncio.wait FIRST_COMPLETED - Race fast and slow tasks, cancel the slower one, and print the first result.
  • Collections usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def main():
    lock = asyncio.Lock()
    counter = 0

    async def worker():
        nonlocal counter
        for _ in range(100):
            async with lock:
                counter += 1

    await asyncio.gather(worker(), worker())
    print(counter)

asyncio.run(main())

lessons.title: contextlib.AsyncExitStack
lessons.description: Use AsyncExitStack to manage two async resources and print their names joined by a comma.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio
from contextlib import AsyncExitStack, asynccontextmanager

@asynccontextmanager
async def connect(name):
    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
    try:
        yield name
    finally:
        await asyncio.sleep(0.01)

async def main():
    # TODO: enter both connections with AsyncExitStack and print "primary,replica"
    pass

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio
from contextlib import AsyncExitStack, asynccontextmanager

@asynccontextmanager
async def connect(name):
    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
    try:
        yield name
    finally:
        await asyncio.sleep(0.01)

async def main():
    async with AsyncExitStack() as stack:
        primary = await stack.enter_async_context(connect("primary"))
        replica = await stack.enter_async_context(connect("replica"))
        print(f"{primary},{replica}")

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:

  • Error Handling usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.title: asyncio.Condition queue
lessons.description: Coordinate a producer and consumer with asyncio.Condition and print items as they are consumed.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def main():
    cond = asyncio.Condition()
    queue = []

    async def producer():
        for item in [1, 2, 3, None]:
            async with cond:
                queue.append(item)
                cond.notify_all()
            await asyncio.sleep(0.01)

    async def consumer():
        while True:
            async with cond:
                while not queue:
                    await cond.wait()
                item = queue.pop(0)
            if item is None:
                print("done")
                return
            print(item)

    # TODO: run producer and consumer and wait for them to finish
    pass

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def main():
    cond = asyncio.Condition()
    queue = []

    async def producer():
        for item in [1, 2, 3, None]:
            async with cond:
                queue.append(item)
                cond.notify_all()
            await asyncio.sleep(0.01)

    async def consumer():
        while True:
            async with cond:
                while not queue:
                    await cond.wait()
                item = queue.pop(0)
            if item is None:
                print("done")
                return
            print(item)

    await asyncio.gather(producer(), consumer())

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:

  • asyncio.Condition queue - Coordinate a producer and consumer with asyncio.Condition and print items as they are consumed.

  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.title: asyncio.TaskGroup fan-in
lessons.description: Launch two coroutines inside asyncio.TaskGroup, collect their results, and print them joined by commas.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def fetch(name, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    return name

async def main():
    # TODO: launch fast and slow under asyncio.TaskGroup and print "fast,slow"
    pass

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def fetch(name, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    return name

async def main():
    async with asyncio.TaskGroup() as tg:
        fast = tg.create_task(fetch("fast", 0.05))
        slow = tg.create_task(fetch("slow", 0.1))
    results = [fast.result(), slow.result()]
    print(",".join(results))

asyncio.run(main())

lessons.title: asyncio.timeout context
lessons.description: Flatten nested lists with mapMulti and print "1 2 3 4". Transform stream elements using the map() operation to create a new stream.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.2)

async def main():
    # TODO: wrap slow() in asyncio.timeout(0.1) and print "timeout" when it expires
    pass

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.2)

async def main():
    try:
        async with asyncio.timeout(0.1):
            await slow()
    except asyncio.TimeoutError:
        print("timeout")
    else:
        print("done")

asyncio.run(main())

lessons.title: asyncio.TaskGroup failures
lessons.description: Handle an ExceptionGroup raised from asyncio.TaskGroup and print the underlying RuntimeError message.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def backend(name, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    if name == "api":
        raise RuntimeError("api down")
    return f"{name} ok"

async def main():
    try:
        async with asyncio.TaskGroup() as tg:
            tg.create_task(backend("api", 0.01))
            tg.create_task(backend("cache", 0.05))
    except* RuntimeError as group:
        # TODO: print the first error message from the exception group
        pass

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def backend(name, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    if name == "api":
        raise RuntimeError("api down")
    return f"{name} ok"

async def main():
    try:
        async with asyncio.TaskGroup() as tg:
            tg.create_task(backend("api", 0.01))
            tg.create_task(backend("cache", 0.05))
    except* RuntimeError as group:
        first = group.exceptions[0]
        print(first.args[0])

asyncio.run(main())

lessons.title: multiprocessing Pool Sum
lessons.description: Capture the rollout steps for adopting virtual threads in a service. Implement concurrent programming with threads for parallel task execution.
lessons.initialCode:
from multiprocessing import Pool

numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]


def square(value: int) -> int:
    return value * value


if __name__ == "__main__":
    # TODO: map the square function across the numbers with a Pool and print the sum
    pass
lessons.fullSolution:
from multiprocessing import Pool

numbers = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]


def square(value: int) -> int:
    return value * value


if __name__ == "__main__":
    with Pool(processes=2) as pool:
        results = pool.map(square, numbers)
    print(sum(results))

lessons.title: asyncio.start_server echo
lessons.description: Load a configuration string with Properties and echo two keys. Advanced programming technique for building robust applications.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def handle(reader, writer):
    data = await reader.read(100)
    # TODO: respond with the data uppercased, flush, then close the connection
    pass

async def main():
    server = await asyncio.start_server(handle, "127.0.0.1", 0)
    addr = server.sockets[0].getsockname()
    async with server:
        reader, writer = await asyncio.open_connection(*addr)
        writer.write(b"devboot")
        await writer.drain()
        data = await reader.read(100)
        writer.close()
        await writer.wait_closed()
    print(data.decode())

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def handle(reader, writer):
    data = await reader.read(100)
    writer.write(data.upper())
    await writer.drain()
    writer.close()
    await writer.wait_closed()

async def main():
    server = await asyncio.start_server(handle, "127.0.0.1", 0)
    addr = server.sockets[0].getsockname()
    async with server:
        reader, writer = await asyncio.open_connection(*addr)
        writer.write(b"devboot")
        await writer.drain()
        data = await reader.read(100)
        writer.close()
        await writer.wait_closed()
    print(data.decode())

asyncio.run(main())

# TODO: seek to the beginning, reopen for reading, gather names, and print them joined by commas
lessons.fullSolution:
import io
import tarfile

buffer = io.BytesIO()
with tarfile.open(fileobj=buffer, mode="w") as tar:
    for name, content in [("a.txt", "A"), ("b.txt", "B")]:
        data = content.encode("utf-8")
        info = tarfile.TarInfo(name)
        info.size = len(data)
        tar.addfile(info, io.BytesIO(data))

buffer.seek(0)
with tarfile.open(fileobj=buffer, mode="r") as tar:
    names = sorted(tar.getnames())
print(",".join(names))

lessons.fullSolution:
import importlib.resources
import sys
import tempfile
from pathlib import Path

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp:
    root = Path(tmp)
    pkg = root / "assets"
    pkg.mkdir()
    (pkg / "__init__.py").write_text("")
    (pkg / "banner.txt").write_text("Launch Ready\n", encoding="utf-8")
    sys.path.insert(0, str(root))
    try:
        assets = __import__("assets")
        text = importlib.resources.files(assets).joinpath("banner.txt").read_text(encoding="utf-8").strip()
        print(text)
    finally:
        sys.path.remove(str(root))

}

)

lessons.fullSolution:
from multiprocessing import shared_memory

seed = shared_memory.ShareableList([14, 17, 21])
SHM_NAME = seed.shm.name
seed.shm.close()
del seed

metrics = shared_memory.ShareableList(name=SHM_NAME)
try:
    for idx in range(len(metrics)):
        metrics[idx] += 1
    print(list(metrics))
finally:
    metrics.shm.close()
    metrics.shm.unlink()

lessons.title: match message router
lessons.description: Use structural pattern matching to route tuple-based messages and handle retries differently for server errors.
lessons.fullSolution:
def handle(message):
    match message:
        case ("ok", value):
            return f"OK:{value}"
        case ("error", {"code": code}) if code >= 500:
            return f"CRITICAL:{code}"
        case ("error", {"code": code}):
            return f"ERROR:{code}"
        case _:
            return "UNKNOWN"

messages = [
    ("ok", 200),
    ("error", {"code": 404}),
    ("error", {"code": 503, "retry": True}),
]

for message in messages:
    print(handle(message))

lessons.title: match class patterns
lessons.description: Dispatch dataclass command objects with class patterns and guards, emitting an audit line for each event.
lessons.fullSolution:
from dataclasses import dataclass

@dataclass
class CreateUser:
    name: str
    role: str

@dataclass
class DeleteUser:
    id: int

def audit(event):
    match event:
        case CreateUser(name=name, role="admin"):
            return f"flag admin signup: {name}"
        case CreateUser(name=name, role=role):
            return f"create {role}: {name}"
        case DeleteUser(id=ident):
            return f"delete {ident}"
        case _:
            return "ignore"

for evt in [
    CreateUser("Ada", "admin"),
    CreateUser("Bob", "guest"),
    DeleteUser(42),
]:
    print(audit(evt))
lessons.expectedOutput:
flag admin signup: Ada
create guest: Bob
delete 42

  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples

Executors.newWorkStealingPool() creates a ForkJoinPool that dynamically balances blocking tasks across threads. invokeAll retains submission order even though work may hop between workers.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions

  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Run blocking service calls on a work-stealing pool and print their results in submission order.

This advanced lesson explores complex patterns used in professional software development.

Pattern:

ExecutorService pool = Executors.newWorkStealingPool();
try {
    List> futures = pool.invokeAll(tasks);
    for (Future future : futures) {
        use(future.get());
    }
} finally {
    pool.shutdown();
}

Work-stealing keeps CPUs busy without manually sizing thread pools for mixed workloads.

    # Print the winning result, cancel the remaining tasks, and wait for their cancellation to settle.

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def fetch(name, delay):
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    return f"{name} ready"

async def main():
    tasks = {
        asyncio.create_task(fetch("primary", 0.08)),
        asyncio.create_task(fetch("replica", 0.02)),
    }
    done, pending = await asyncio.wait(tasks, return_when=asyncio.FIRST_COMPLETED)
    winner = done.pop()
    print(await winner)
    for task in pending:
        task.cancel()
    await asyncio.gather(*pending, return_exceptions=True)

asyncio.run(main())

Writers take the exclusive lock while readers share the read lock. By waiting for the writer to hold the lock before launching readers, you ensure they block until the update is committed and then observe the fresh snapshot.

This advanced lesson explores complex patterns used in professional software development.

Pattern:

lock.writeLock().lock();
try {
    update();
} finally {
    lock.writeLock().unlock();
}

lock.readLock().lock();
try {
    use();
} finally {
    lock.readLock().unlock();
}

    # Print each non-None payload as it arrives

async def main():
    queue = asyncio.Queue()
    await asyncio.gather(
        producer("alpha", [("ping", 0.01), ("done", 0.03)], queue),

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def producer(name, delays, queue):
    for message, delay in delays:
        await asyncio.sleep(delay)
        await queue.put(f"{name}:{message}")
    await queue.put(None)

async def consumer(queue, producers):
    finished = 0
    while finished < producers:
        item = await queue.get()
        if item is None:
            finished += 1
        else:
            print(item)

async def main():
    queue = asyncio.Queue()
    await asyncio.gather(
        producer("alpha", [("ping", 0.01), ("done", 0.03)], queue),
        producer("beta", [("sync", 0.02)], queue),
        consumer(queue, 2),
    )

asyncio.run(main())

Key Concepts

  • asyncio.Queue fan-in - Collect messages from multiple producers through an asyncio.Queue and emit them in the order they arrive.
  • Async usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections

lessons.title: asyncio.Condition broadcast
lessons.description: Use asyncio.Condition to block multiple waiters until a notifier releases them, printing the coordination steps.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def worker(name, condition):
    async with condition:
        print(f"{name} waiting")
        await condition.wait()
        print(f"{name} go")

async def release(condition):
    await asyncio.sleep(0.03)
    async with condition:
        print("notifying")
        condition.notify_all()

async def main():
    condition = asyncio.Condition()
    await asyncio.gather(
        worker("alpha", condition),
        worker("beta", condition),
        release(condition),
    )
    print("all clear")

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def worker(name, condition):
    async with condition:
        print(f"{name} waiting")
        await condition.wait()
        print(f"{name} go")

async def release(condition):
    await asyncio.sleep(0.03)
    async with condition:
        print("notifying")
        condition.notify_all()

async def main():
    condition = asyncio.Condition()
    await asyncio.gather(
        worker("alpha", condition),
        worker("beta", condition),
        release(condition),
    )
    print("all clear")

asyncio.run(main())

StampedLock allows optimistic reads that avoid locking when no writer interferes. Validate the stamp; if it has been invalidated by a write, fall back to a read lock.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Use StampedLock to take an optimistic read snapshot and fall back to the read lock if contention occurs.

This advanced lesson explores complex patterns used in professional software development.

Pattern:

long stamp = lock.tryOptimisticRead();\nT value = snapshot();\nif (!lock.validate(stamp)) {\n    stamp = lock.readLock();\n    try {\n        value = snapshot();\n    } finally {\n        lock.unlockRead(stamp);\n    }\n}

Optimistic reads shine when writers are rare and you want minimal reader contention.

Practical Applications:

Understanding stampedlock optimistic read is essential for writing effective Java code. This concept appears frequently in real-world applications and is a building block for more advanced patterns.

lessons.fullSolution:
from pathlib import Path
import tempfile
import os

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp:
    root = Path(tmp)
    (root / 'logs').mkdir()
    (root / 'logs' / 'app.log').write_text('ok')
    (root / 'logs' / 'api.log').write_text('ok')
    (root / 'tmp').mkdir()
    (root / 'tmp' / 'scratch.txt').write_text('tmp')
    (root / 'README.md').write_text('notes')

    files = []
    walker = getattr(root, 'walk', None)
    if walker is None:  # Python < 3.12 fallback
        iterator = ((Path(current), dirs, filenames) for current, dirs, filenames in os.walk(root))
    else:
        iterator = walker()
    for current, _dirs, filenames in iterator:
        current_path = Path(current)
        for name in filenames:
            rel = (current_path / name).relative_to(root).as_posix()
            files.append(rel)
    for path in sorted(files):
        print(path)
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • pathlib.Path.walk inventory - Traverse a directory tree with Path.walk(), collect discovered files, and print their relative paths alphabetically.
  • Control Flow usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Functional programming approach for declarative data processing pipelines

lessons.title: statistics.linear_regression trend
lessons.description: Fit a simple linear regression to quarterly signups and project next quarter.
lessons.initialCode:
try:
    from statistics import linear_regression
except ImportError:
    from collections import namedtuple

    def linear_regression(xs, ys):
        n = len(xs)
        mean_x = sum(xs) / n
        mean_y = sum(ys) / n
        num = sum((x - mean_x) * (y - mean_y) for x, y in zip(xs, ys))
        den = sum((x - mean_x) ** 2 for x in xs)
        slope = num / den
        intercept = mean_y - slope * mean_x
        Regression = namedtuple('LinearRegression', 'slope intercept')
        return Regression(slope, intercept)

quarters = [1, 2, 3, 4]
signups = [120, 150, 170, 210]

# TODO: call linear_regression to get slope and intercept
# Print slope and intercept with two decimals as slope:<value> and intercept:<value>
# Compute quarter 5 projection and print q5:<value> with two decimals
lessons.fullSolution:
try:
    from statistics import linear_regression
except ImportError:
    from collections import namedtuple

    def linear_regression(xs, ys):
        n = len(xs)
        mean_x = sum(xs) / n
        mean_y = sum(ys) / n
        num = sum((x - mean_x) * (y - mean_y) for x, y in zip(xs, ys))
        den = sum((x - mean_x) ** 2 for x in xs)
        slope = num / den
        intercept = mean_y - slope * mean_x
        Regression = namedtuple('LinearRegression', 'slope intercept')
        return Regression(slope, intercept)

quarters = [1, 2, 3, 4]
signups = [120, 150, 170, 210]

trend = linear_regression(quarters, signups)
print(f"slope:{trend.slope:.2f}")
print(f"intercept:{trend.intercept:.2f}")
projection = trend.slope * 5 + trend.intercept
print(f"q5:{projection:.2f}")

lessons.initialCode:
import os
import subprocess
import sys
import zipapp
from pathlib import Path
import tempfile

run_root = Path(os.environ.get('RUN_TMP_DIR') or tempfile.gettempdir())
app_dir = run_root / 'deploy_app'

# TODO: ensure app_dir/__main__.py prints "Hello from pyz"
# Build the archive with zipapp.create_archive
# Run the archive with subprocess.run([sys.executable, str(archive_path)]) capturing stdout
# Print "Created deploy_app.pyz" and then "Run output: <captured output>"
lessons.fullSolution:
import os
import subprocess
import sys
import zipapp
from pathlib import Path
import tempfile

run_root = Path(os.environ.get('RUN_TMP_DIR') or tempfile.gettempdir())
app_dir = run_root / 'deploy_app'
archive_path = run_root / 'deploy_app.pyz'

app_dir.mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True)
(app_dir / '__main__.py').write_text("print('Hello from pyz')\n", encoding='utf-8')
try:
    archive_path.unlink()
except FileNotFoundError:
    pass

zipapp.create_archive(app_dir, archive_path)
print(f"Created {archive_path.name}")
result = subprocess.run([sys.executable, str(archive_path)], check=True, capture_output=True, text=True)
print(f"Run output: {result.stdout.strip()}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Created deploy_app.pyz
Run output: Hello from pyz

import os import shutil import tempfile from pathlib import Path import zipfile run_root = Path(os.environ.get('RUN_TMP_DIR') or tempfile.gettempdir()) site_dir = run_root / 'static_site' archive_base = run_root / 'static_site' archive_path = archive_base.with_suffix('.zip') if site_dir.exists(): shutil.rmtree(site_dir) if archive_path.exists(): archive_path.unlink() (site_dir / 'assets').mkdir(parents=True, exist_ok=True) (site_dir / 'index.html').write_text('

Launch

lessons.fullSolution:
from typing import Callable, TypeVarTuple, Unpack

Ts = TypeVarTuple("Ts")

def call_with_prefix(prefix: str, fn: Callable[[Unpack[Ts]], str], *args: Unpack[Ts]) -> str:
    result = fn(*args)
    return f"{prefix}: {result}"

def describe(name: str, age: int, active: bool) -> str:
    state = "active" if active else "inactive"
    return f"{name} ({age}) is {state}"

print(call_with_prefix("team", describe, "Ada", 36, True))

lessons.title: asyncio.Barrier coordination
lessons.description: Coordinate two async workers with asyncio.Barrier so they launch together, then print the recorded timeline.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def worker(name: str, delay: float, barrier: asyncio.Barrier, events: list[str]) -> None:
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    events.append(f"{name} staged")
    await barrier.wait()
    await asyncio.sleep(delay / 2)
    events.append(f"{name} running")


async def main() -> None:
    barrier = asyncio.Barrier(3)
    events: list[str] = []

    # TODO: start two workers (alpha delay 0.01, beta delay 0.02).
    # Let both reach the barrier, append "launch" to events, and
    # have main await the barrier before gathering the tasks.
    # Finally, print each event in events on its own line.


asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def worker(name: str, delay: float, barrier: asyncio.Barrier, events: list[str]) -> None:
    await asyncio.sleep(delay)
    events.append(f"{name} staged")
    await barrier.wait()
    await asyncio.sleep(delay / 2)
    events.append(f"{name} running")


async def main() -> None:
    barrier = asyncio.Barrier(3)
    events: list[str] = []

    tasks = [
        asyncio.create_task(worker("alpha", 0.01, barrier, events)),
        asyncio.create_task(worker("beta", 0.02, barrier, events)),
    ]

    await asyncio.sleep(0.03)
    events.append("launch")
    await barrier.wait()
    await asyncio.gather(*tasks)

    for entry in events:
        print(entry)


asyncio.run(main())
lessons.expectedOutput:
alpha staged
beta staged
launch
alpha running
beta running
lessons.tutorial:

  • asyncio.Barrier coordination - Coordinate two async workers with asyncio.Barrier so they launch together, then print the recorded timeline.
  • Lifecycle usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Resources usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.fullSolution:
from typing import NotRequired, Required, TypedDict

class ServiceConfig(TypedDict):
    host: Required[str]
    port: NotRequired[int]
    secure: NotRequired[bool]

config: ServiceConfig = {"host": "api.local"}
config["secure"] = False
config["port"] = 8080

def format_url(cfg: ServiceConfig) -> str:
    port = cfg.get("port", 80)
    scheme = "https" if cfg.get("secure", False) else "http"
    return f"{scheme}://{cfg['host']}:{port}"

print(format_url(config))

WatchService lets you react to filesystem changes without polling. Register the directory once, then block on watch.take() for incoming events.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Watch a temporary directory for file creation and print the resulting event. Advanced programming technique for building robust applications.

This expert-level lesson covers advanced techniques for building robust production systems.

Pattern:

dir.register(watch, StandardWatchEventKinds.ENTRY_CREATE);
Files.writeString(file, "data");
boolean printed = false;
while (!printed) {
    WatchKey key = watch.take();
    for (WatchEvent<?> event : key.pollEvents()) {
        if (event.kind() == StandardWatchEventKinds.OVERFLOW) continue;
        if (event.kind() == StandardWatchEventKinds.ENTRY_CREATE) {
            Path name = (Path) event.context();
            System.out.println(event.kind().name() + ":" + name);
            printed = true;
            break;
        }
    }
    key.reset();
}

Always delete temporary fixtures and ignore OVERFLOW signals so bursts of activity do not break your pipeline.

lessons.title: contextlib.chdir temporary cwd
lessons.description: Temporarily change the working directory with contextlib.chdir to read a file by relative path.
lessons.initialCode:
import tempfile
from pathlib import Path

try:
    from contextlib import chdir
except ImportError:
    from contextlib import contextmanager
    import os

    @contextmanager
    def chdir(path):
        previous = os.getcwd()
        os.chdir(path)
        try:
            yield
        finally:
            os.chdir(previous)

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp:
    root = Path(tmp)
    reports = root / "reports"
    reports.mkdir()
    summary = reports / "summary.txt"
    summary.write_text("ready\n", encoding="utf-8")

    print("outside")
    # TODO: enter reports with chdir and print "inside: <line>" from summary.txt
    print("outside")
lessons.fullSolution:
import tempfile
from pathlib import Path

try:
    from contextlib import chdir
except ImportError:
    from contextlib import contextmanager
    import os

    @contextmanager
    def chdir(path):
        previous = os.getcwd()
        os.chdir(path)
        try:
            yield
        finally:
            os.chdir(previous)

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp:
    root = Path(tmp)
    reports = root / "reports"
    reports.mkdir()
    summary = reports / "summary.txt"
    summary.write_text("ready\n", encoding="utf-8")

    print("outside")
    with chdir(reports):
        line = Path("summary.txt").read_text(encoding="utf-8").strip()
        print(f"inside: {line}")
    print("outside")
lessons.tutorial:

  • NIO usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.description: Guarantee an async generator closes even when the consumer breaks early by wrapping it with contextlib.aclosing.
lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio
from contextlib import aclosing

async def ticker():
    try:
        for item in ["alpha", "beta", "gamma"]:
            await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
            yield item
    finally:
        print("cleanup")

async def main():
    collected: list[str] = []
    # TODO: wrap ticker() with aclosing, take the first two items, then exit the loop
    # After the context exits, print the collected items joined by commas

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio
from contextlib import aclosing

async def ticker():
    try:
        for item in ["alpha", "beta", "gamma"]:
            await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
            yield item
    finally:
        print("cleanup")

async def main():
    collected: list[str] = []
    async with aclosing(ticker()) as stream:
        async for item in stream:
            collected.append(item)
            if len(collected) == 2:
                break
    print(",".join(collected))

asyncio.run(main())

        zf.writestr("logs/", "")
        zf.writestr("logs/app.log", "ready\n")

    # TODO: reopen the archive, wrap the "logs" directory with zipfile.Path,
    # print its child names joined by commas, then read logs/app.log without extracting
lessons.fullSolution:
import tempfile
import zipfile
from pathlib import Path

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp:
    root = Path(tmp)
    archive = root / "logs.zip"
    with zipfile.ZipFile(archive, "w") as zf:
        zf.writestr("logs/", "")
        zf.writestr("logs/app.log", "ready\n")
        zf.writestr("logs/error.log", "failed\n")

    with zipfile.ZipFile(archive) as zf:
        root_path = zipfile.Path(zf)
        logs = root_path / "logs"
        names = sorted(child.name for child in logs.iterdir())
        print(",".join(names))

        app_log = logs / "app.log"
        with app_log.open("r", encoding="utf-8") as handle:
            print(handle.read().strip())

    Future future = executor.submit(() -> {
        TimeUnit.MILLISECONDS.sleep(10);
        return "ready";

    System.out.println(future.get());
}

Gathering futures in submission order makes it easy to preserve deterministic output even though the tasks complete out of order.

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def fetch_user():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
    return "alex"

async def fetch_account():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.02)
    return "pro"

async def main():
    async with asyncio.TaskGroup() as tg:
        user_task = tg.create_task(fetch_user())
        account_task = tg.create_task(fetch_account())
    combined = f"{user_task.result()}-{account_task.result()}"
    print(combined)

asyncio.run(main())

Overview

Acquire a VarHandle for an int array element, atomically add to it with a compare-and-set loop, and print the updated value.

This expert-level lesson covers advanced techniques for building robust production systems.

Pattern:

VarHandle handle = MethodHandles.arrayElementVarHandle(int[].class);
int value;
do {
    value = (int) handle.getVolatile(array, index);
} while (!handle.compareAndSet(array, index, value, value + delta));

The volatile access keeps other threads from caching stale values, making this a safe lock-free increment.

Structured concurrency scopes let you launch related subtasks and coordinate their lifetime. ShutdownOnFailure cancels sibling work if any fork fails.

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions

Overview

Run two blocking operations inside a StructuredTaskScope, wait for completion, and print their combined result.

This expert-level lesson covers advanced techniques for building robust production systems.

Pattern:

try (var scope = new StructuredTaskScope.ShutdownOnFailure()) {
    var a = scope.fork(this::loadA);
    var b = scope.fork(this::loadB);
    scope.join();
    scope.throwIfFailed();
    return combine(a.get(), b.get());
}

Always call join() followed by throwIfFailed() so exceptions surface before you use the subtasks' results.

lessons.title: functools.reduce summary
lessons.description: Use functools.reduce to track total, count, and max in one pass, then print the average and maximum score.
lessons.initialCode:
from functools import reduce

scores = [10, 20, 30, 40]

# TODO: use reduce with an accumulator of (total, count, max)
# and print "avg=25.0,max=40"
lessons.fullSolution:
from functools import reduce

scores = [10, 20, 30, 40]

def step(acc, value):
    total, count, maximum = acc
    maximum = value if maximum is None else max(maximum, value)
    return total + value, count + 1, maximum

total, count, maximum = reduce(step, scores, (0, 0, None))
average = total / count if count else 0.0
print(f"avg={average:.1f},max={maximum}")

lessons.title: multiprocessing.Value atomic update
lessons.description: Use a multiprocessing.Value and its lock to perform an atomic add, emulating a compare-and-set loop.
lessons.initialCode:
from multiprocessing import Value

counter = Value('i', 3)

def atomic_add(amount: int) -> int:
    # TODO: grab the Value's lock, read the current value,
    # write back the incremented value, and return it
    raise NotImplementedError

print(atomic_add(4))
lessons.fullSolution:
from multiprocessing import Value

counter = Value('i', 3)

def atomic_add(amount: int) -> int:
    while True:
        with counter.get_lock():
            current = counter.value
            new_value = current + amount
            counter.value = new_value
            return new_value

print(atomic_add(4))

lessons.initialCode:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.04)
    return "slow"

async def fast():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
    return "fast"

    # TODO: start slow() and fast() as tasks, wait until one finishes,
    # print its result, then print the results of the slow and fast tasks in that order
    pass

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def slow():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.04)
    return "slow"

async def fast():
    await asyncio.sleep(0.01)
    return "fast"

async def main():
    slow_task = asyncio.create_task(slow())
    fast_task = asyncio.create_task(fast())

    done, pending = await asyncio.wait({slow_task, fast_task}, return_when=asyncio.FIRST_COMPLETED)
    winner_task = done.pop()
    print(winner_task.result())
    print(await slow_task)
    print(await fast_task)

asyncio.run(main())

from urllib.parse import urlencode
from urllib.request import Request

base_url = "https://status.example/api/health"

url = f"{base_url}?{urlencode(params)}"
request = Request(url, method="GET", headers={"Accept": "application/json"})

print(request.get_method())
print(request.headers.get("Accept"))

lessons.fullSolution:
import os
import tempfile
from pathlib import Path

with tempfile.TemporaryDirectory() as tmp:
    root = Path(tmp)
    (root / "logs" / "archive").mkdir(parents=True)
    (root / "config").mkdir()

    total = sum(1 for _ in os.walk(root))
    print(total)
lessons.tutorial:

FileVisitor gives you fine-grained control over directory traversal. Override preVisitDirectory to act on each folder before its contents are explored.

Overview

Pattern:

Files.walkFileTree(root, new SimpleFileVisitor<>() {
    @Override
    public FileVisitResult preVisitDirectory(Path dir, BasicFileAttributes attrs) {
        directories.incrementAndGet();
        return FileVisitResult.CONTINUE;
    }
});

Sort the cleanup walk in reverse so children are removed before parents; otherwise directories refuse to delete.

lessons.title: zoneinfo time conversions
lessons.description: Convert an instant to multiple time zones with zoneinfo and print formatted timestamps.
lessons.initialCode:
from datetime import datetime
from zoneinfo import ZoneInfo

instant = datetime.fromisoformat("2024-05-25T12:30:00+00:00")

# TODO: show this instant in Asia/Seoul and America/New_York using "YYYY-MM-DD HH:MM ±HH:MM"
# Print the Seoul time first, then New York
lessons.fullSolution:
from datetime import datetime
from zoneinfo import ZoneInfo

instant = datetime.fromisoformat("2024-05-25T12:30:00+00:00")
seoul = instant.astimezone(ZoneInfo("Asia/Seoul"))
new_york = seoul.astimezone(ZoneInfo("America/New_York"))

def fmt(dt: datetime) -> str:
    offset = dt.strftime("%z")
    offset = f"{offset[:3]}:{offset[3:]}"
    return f"{dt.strftime('%Y-%m-%d %H:%M')} {offset}"

print(fmt(seoul))
print(fmt(new_york))

lessons.title: as_completed ordering
lessons.description: Submit tasks with different sleep durations to ThreadPoolExecutor, iterate futures via concurrent.futures.as_completed, print each result, and shut down the pool.
lessons.initialCode:
import concurrent.futures
import time

work = [
    ("slow", 0.025),
    ("steady", 0.015),
    ("fast", 0.005),
]

# TODO: submit the work items to a ThreadPoolExecutor and print results as they complete
lessons.fullSolution:
import concurrent.futures
import time

work = [
    ("slow", 0.025),
    ("steady", 0.015),
    ("fast", 0.005),
]

def run(label: str, delay: float) -> str:
    time.sleep(delay)
    return label

with concurrent.futures.ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=3) as executor:
    futures = [executor.submit(run, label, delay) for label, delay in work]
    for future in concurrent.futures.as_completed(futures):
        print(future.result())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • as_completed ordering - Submit tasks with different sleep durations to ThreadPoolExecutor, iterate futures via concurrent.futures.as_completed,
  • Managing multiple threads safely using synchronization and thread-safe collections
  • ExecutorService usage demonstrated through practical examples

ExecutorCompletionService hands back futures in completion order, so faster tasks surface first even if they were submitted later.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Overview

Submit tasks with different durations to an ExecutorCompletionService, print results as soon as each completes, then shut down the executor.

This expert-level lesson covers advanced techniques for building robust production systems.

Pattern:

CompletionService service = new ExecutorCompletionService<>(executor);
tasks.forEach(service::submit);
for (int i = 0; i < tasks.size(); i++) {
    System.out.println(service.take().get());
}

Always shut down the executor in a finally block so threads exit once work is finished.

Practical Applications:

lessons.title: ContextVar with context manager
lessons.description: Manage a ContextVar using a context manager so values restore automatically after nested scopes.
lessons.initialCode:
from contextlib import contextmanager
from contextvars import ContextVar

current_user: ContextVar[str] = ContextVar("current_user", default="guest")

@contextmanager
def user(name: str):
    # TODO: set the context var, yield control, then restore the previous value
    yield

print(f"outer={current_user.get()}")
with user("alex"):
    print(f"inside={current_user.get()}")
    with user("jamie"):
        print(f"nested={current_user.get()}")
    print(f"after nested={current_user.get()}")
print(f"after outer={current_user.get()}")
lessons.fullSolution:
from contextlib import contextmanager
from contextvars import ContextVar

current_user: ContextVar[str] = ContextVar("current_user", default="guest")

@contextmanager
def user(name: str):
    token = current_user.set(name)
    try:
        yield
    finally:
        current_user.reset(token)

print(f"outer={current_user.get()}")
with user("alex"):
    print(f"inside={current_user.get()}")
    with user("jamie"):
        print(f"nested={current_user.get()}")
    print(f"after nested={current_user.get()}")
print(f"after outer={current_user.get()}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
outer=guest
inside=alex
nested=jamie
after nested=alex
after outer=guest
lessons.tutorial:

  • ContextVar with context manager - Manage a ContextVar using a context manager so values restore automatically after nested scopes.
  • Collections usage demonstrated through practical examples

lessons.fullSolution:
import asyncio

async def fetch_status(host: str, path: str = "/") -> int:
    reader, writer = await asyncio.open_connection(host, 80)
    request = f"GET {path} HTTP/1.1\r\nHost: {host}\r\nConnection: close\r\n\r\n"
    writer.write(request.encode("ascii"))
    await writer.drain()
    status_line = await reader.readline()
    writer.close()
    await writer.wait_closed()
    parts = status_line.decode("ascii").split()
    return int(parts[1])

async def main():
    status = await fetch_status("example.com")
    print(status)

asyncio.run(main())
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • asyncio HTTP status - Fetch example.com using asyncio sockets, parse the HTTP status code, and print it when complete.
  • Async usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • HTTP usage demonstrated through practical examples

    file1 = f1.name

# TODO: get last modified times, compare them, and print "newer" or "older"

lessons.fullSolution:
import tempfile
import os
import time

with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False) as f1:
    file1 = f1.name
time.sleep(0.01)
with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(delete=False) as f2:
    file2 = f2.name

time1 = os.path.getmtime(file1)
time2 = os.path.getmtime(file2)

result = "newer" if time2 > time1 else "older"
print(result)

lessons.title: Write and read config file
lessons.description: Write key-value pairs to an INI config file using configparser, then read them back and print a specific value.
lessons.initialCode:
import configparser
import tempfile
import os

filename = os.path.join(tempfile.gettempdir(), "app.ini")

# TODO: create ConfigParser, add section "settings" with "user"="alice" and "role"="admin",
# write to file, read back, and print the "user" value
lessons.fullSolution:
import configparser
import tempfile
import os

filename = os.path.join(tempfile.gettempdir(), "app.ini")
config = configparser.ConfigParser()
config["settings"] = {"user": "alice", "role": "admin"}

with open(filename, "w") as f:
    config.write(f)

loaded = configparser.ConfigParser()
loaded.read(filename)
print(loaded["settings"]["user"])

lessons.initialCode:

    time.sleep(0.1)
    # TODO: set the event to signal completion

lessons.fullSolution:
import threading
import time

event = threading.Event()

def worker():
    time.sleep(0.1)
    event.set()

event.wait()
print("done")

lessons.initialCode:

    # TODO: call barrier.wait()

# TODO: start worker thread, sleep briefly, call barrier.wait() in main
lessons.fullSolution:
import threading
import time

barrier = threading.Barrier(2, action=lambda: print("ready"))

def worker():
    barrier.wait()

thread = threading.Thread(target=worker)
thread.start()
time.sleep(0.05)
barrier.wait()
thread.join()
lessons.tutorial:

lessons.title: Reading environment variables with os.environ
lessons.description: Learn how to read environment variables using System.getenv() in Java Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
lessons.initialCode:
import os

# Read the PATH environment variable
path = os.environ.get('PATH')
print(f"PATH exists: {path is not None}")

# TODO: Read the USER or USERNAME environment variable
# TODO: Count all environment variables
lessons.fullSolution:
import os

# Read the PATH environment variable
path = os.environ.get('PATH')
print(f"PATH exists: {path is not None}")

# Read the USER or USERNAME environment variable
user = os.environ.get('USER') or os.environ.get('USERNAME', 'unknown')
print(f"User: {user}")

# Count all environment variables
count = len(os.environ)
print(f"Total environment variables: {count}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
PATH exists: True
User: [username]
Total environment variables: [count]
lessons.tutorial:
Overview

Environment variables allow you to configure applications without hardcoding values. Reading them properly is essential for deployable, secure applications that work across different environments (dev, staging, production).

Key Concepts

  • Reading environment variables - Core technique for this lesson
  • CLI - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • Workflow - Applied in this lesson's implementation

Reading Environment Variables in Java

Environment variables are key-value pairs provided by the operating system that allow configuration without changing code.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Basic Usage

Read a single environment variable: 
String path = System.getenv("PATH");
if (path != null) {
    System.out.println("PATH: " + path);
} else {
    System.out.println("PATH not set");
}

Reading All Variables

Get all environment variables as a Map: 
Map env = System.getenv();
for (Map.Entry entry : env.entrySet()) {
    System.out.println(entry.getKey() + " = " + entry.getValue());
}

Cross-Platform Variable Names

Different operating systems use different variable names: 
// Get username (cross-platform)
String user = System.getenv("USER");  // Unix/Linux/Mac
if (user == null) {
    user = System.getenv("USERNAME");  // Windows
}
System.out.println("Current user: " + user);
// Get home directory
String home = System.getenv("HOME");  // Unix
if (home == null) {
    home = System.getenv("USERPROFILE");  // Windows
}

Common Environment Variables

  • PATH: Directories to search for executables
  • HOME (Unix) / USERPROFILE (Windows): User's home directory
  • USER (Unix) / USERNAME (Windows): Current username
  • JAVA_HOME: Java installation directory
  • TEMP / TMP: Temporary files directory

Best Practices

  • Always check for null: Variables may not be set
  • Handle platform differences: Use fallback logic for OS-specific variables
  • Don't rely on case: Variable names are case-sensitive on Unix, case-insensitive on Windows
  • Security: Never log sensitive environment variables (API keys, passwords)

When to Use

  • Reading system configuration
  • Detecting runtime environment
  • Finding system directories
  • Getting user information
  • CI/CD pipeline configuration

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

Further Learning:

Build on this foundation by exploring related concepts and practicing with real-world scenarios.

lessons.fullSolution:
import os

# Read APP_NAME with default
app_name = os.environ.get('APP_NAME', 'MyApp')
print(f"App: {app_name}")

# Read PORT with default 8080 (as integer)

App: MyApp

lessons.tutorial:
Overview

Providing sensible defaults for environment variables makes your application more robust and easier to configure. This lesson shows how to handle missing environment variables gracefully with fallback values.

Key Concepts

  • Default environment variable values - Core technique for this lesson
  • CLI - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • Workflow - Applied in this lesson's implementation

Default Environment Variable Values in Java

Providing default values makes your application more robust and easier to configure.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Reading with Defaults

The basic pattern for environment variables with defaults: 
private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
    String value = System.getenv(name);
    return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
}
// Usage
String appName = getEnvOrDefault("APP_NAME", "MyApp");
String port = getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080");

Type Conversion

Since environment variables are always strings, you need to convert them: 
// Integer
int port = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080"));
// Boolean
boolean debug = Boolean.parseBoolean(getEnvOrDefault("DEBUG", "false"));
// With error handling
int timeout;
try {
    timeout = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("TIMEOUT", "30"));
} catch (NumberFormatException e) {
    timeout = 30; // fallback default
}

Configuration Class Pattern

For complex applications, create a configuration class: 
public class AppConfig {
    public static final String APP_NAME = getEnvOrDefault("APP_NAME", "MyApp");
    public static final int PORT = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("PORT", "8080"));
    public static final String LOG_LEVEL = getEnvOrDefault("LOG_LEVEL", "INFO");
    private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
        String value = System.getenv(name);
        return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
    }
}

Best Practices

  • Document all variables: Maintain a README or .env.example file listing all expected environment variables
  • Use sensible defaults: Development-friendly defaults reduce configuration burden
  • Validate after parsing: Check that converted values are in acceptable ranges
  • Fail fast: For required variables without good defaults, fail early with clear error messages

When to Use

  • Configuring server ports, database URLs, API keys
  • Feature flags and debug modes
  • Environment-specific settings (dev/staging/prod)
  • Docker and cloud deployments

Example: Complete Configuration

public class DatabaseConfig {
    private final String host;
    private final int port;
    private final String database;
    public DatabaseConfig() {
        this.host = getEnvOrDefault("DB_HOST", "localhost");
        this.port = Integer.parseInt(getEnvOrDefault("DB_PORT", "5432"));
        this.database = getEnvOrDefault("DB_NAME", "myapp");
        validate();
    }
    private void validate() {
        if (port < 1 || port > 65535) {
            throw new IllegalArgumentException("Invalid port: " + port);
        }
    }
    private static String getEnvOrDefault(String name, String defaultValue) {
        String value = System.getenv(name);
        return value != null ? value : defaultValue;
    }
}

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Logging with multiple levels - Learn how to use different logging levels in Java Intermediate concept building on fundamental programming skills.
  • Debugging usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Tooling usage demonstrated through practical examples

Java's logging framework provides a hierarchical system for tracking application behavior, debugging issues, and monitoring production systems. The java.util.logging package offers five primary logging levels (SEVERE, WARNING, INFO, CONFIG, FINE) that help developers categorize message importance. Understanding logging levels is crucial for effective debugging and system monitoring in enterprise applications where you need to track what's happening across distributed components.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully
  • Not considering performance implications for large datasets

Basic Pattern

import java.util.logging.;
Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(MyClass.class.getName());
logger.severe("Critical error occurred");
logger.warning("Potential issue detected");
logger.info("Normal operation message");

Advanced Usage

import java.util.logging.;
public class LoggerDemo {
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(LoggerDemo.class.getName());
    static {
        logger.setLevel(Level.ALL);
        ConsoleHandler handler = new ConsoleHandler();
        handler.setLevel(Level.ALL);
        logger.addHandler(handler);
        logger.setUseParentHandlers(false);
    }
    public void processData(String data) {
        logger.fine("Processing started: " + data);
        logger.config("Configuration loaded");
        logger.info("Data processed successfully");
    }
}

Complete Example

import java.util.logging.*;
public class Main {
    private static final Logger logger = Logger.getLogger(Main.class.getName());
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        try {
            logger.info("Application started");
            int result = divide(10, 0);
            logger.info("Result: " + result);
        } catch (Exception e) {
            logger.severe("Exception occurred: " + e.getMessage());
            logger.warning("Using default value");
        } finally {
            logger.info("Application shutdown");
        }
    }
    static int divide(int a, int b) {
        logger.fine("Dividing " + a + " by " + b);
        return a / b;
    }
}

Common Use Cases

  • Error tracking: Log exceptions and error conditions with SEVERE level for immediate attention
  • Debugging production issues: Use INFO and FINE levels to trace application flow without overwhelming logs
  • Performance monitoring: Track operation timing and resource usage with appropriate log levels
  • Audit trails: Record user actions and system events for compliance and security analysis

Best Practices

  • Use appropriate log levels consistently across your application (SEVERE for errors, WARNING for issues, INFO for milestones)
  • Include contextual information in log messages (user IDs, transaction IDs, timestamps)
  • Configure log levels externally via properties files rather than hard-coding in source
  • Avoid logging sensitive data (passwords, credit cards, personal information)
  • Use parameterized logging for better performance: logger.log(Level.INFO, "User {0} logged in", userId)

When to Use

Use Java logging when building production applications that require monitoring and debugging capabilities, when you need hierarchical logger control across modules, when compliance requires audit trails, or when you're working in enterprise environments with centralized logging systems. Logging is essential for diagnosing issues in deployed applications where debuggers aren't available.

Overview

lessons.fullSolution:

# Create custom formatter

    '[%(asctime)s] %(levelname)s: %(message)s',
    datefmt='%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S'
)
