lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Design Instagram/Image Service - Design a photo sharing service with image upload, storage, thumbnails, and CDN delivery
  • CDN usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Caching usage demonstrated through practical examples

System Design: Instagram Image Service

Overview

Design a photo sharing service with image upload, storage, thumbnails, and CDN delivery

This lesson focuses on concepts frequently tested in FAANG interviews. Understanding this topic is crucial for technical interview success.

Introduction

Instagram handles 500M+ photos daily with instant uploads, multiple sizes, and global CDN delivery. This system requires efficient storage, processing pipelines, and content delivery optimization.

Requirements

  • Functional: Upload photos, generate thumbnails, serve via CDN, support filters
  • Non-Functional: 500M photos/day, <200ms upload, 10B requests/day, 99.99% availability
  • Scale: 500M photos × 2MB avg = 1 PB/day storage

Architecture Components

  • Upload Service: Handles image upload, validates format/size
  • Processing Pipeline: Async thumbnail generation (150x150, 720p, 1080p)
  • Storage: S3 for originals, CloudFront CDN for delivery
  • Metadata DB: PostgreSQL for photo metadata (user_id, location, tags)

Image Processing Pipeline

1. User uploads image → Upload Service
2. Store original in S3 (s3://instagram/original/G8.jpg)
3. Publish to SQS queue: {imageId: G8, s3Key: ...}
4. Worker picks from queue, generates sizes:
   - Thumbnail: 150x150 (for feed)
   - Medium: 720p (for mobile)
   - Large: 1080p (for desktop)
5. Store processed images in S3
6. Update metadata DB with URLs
7. Purge CDN cache if needed

Storage Strategy

  • Hot Storage (recent): S3 Standard for photos <30 days
  • Warm Storage: S3 Infrequent Access for 30-365 days
  • Cold Storage: Glacier for >1 year old photos
  • Cost: $0.023/GB (Standard) → $0.0125/GB (IA) → $0.004/GB (Glacier)

CDN Strategy

// CloudFront distribution setup
Origin: S3 bucket (instagram-images)
Edge locations: 400+ globally
Cache TTL: 1 year (images never change)
Query string forwarding: Yes (for size param)

URL structure:
https://cdn.instagram.com/G8_150x150.jpg
https://cdn.instagram.com/G8_1080p.jpg

Database Schema

Table: photos
+-----------+------------------+
| id        | VARCHAR(10) PK   |
| user_id   | BIGINT           |
| caption   | TEXT             |
| location  | POINT (lat,lng)  |
| s3_key    | VARCHAR(256)     |
| cdn_url   | VARCHAR(512)     |
| width     | INT              |
| height    | INT              |
| filter    | VARCHAR(50)      |
| likes     | INT DEFAULT 0    |
| created   | TIMESTAMP        |
+-----------+------------------+

Indexes:
- user_id (user's photos)
- location (geo search)
- created (timeline)

Scaling Techniques

  • Upload: Multipart upload for large files (>5MB)
  • Processing: Horizontal scaling of worker pool (SQS + EC2 Auto Scaling)
  • Delivery: CDN caching (95% requests served from edge)
  • Database: Read replicas for metadata queries

Real-World Examples

Instagram: Uses Facebook's Haystack for photo storage. 1 trillion photos stored. CDN serves 200+ PB daily.

Pinterest: Stores images in S3, uses CloudFront. Async processing with SQS. 300B image views/month.

Imgur: Handles 2.5M image uploads/day. Uses imgix for on-the-fly resizing and optimization.

Interview Discussion Points

  • Trade-offs: Pre-generate all sizes vs on-demand resizing?
  • Consistency: Eventual consistency OK (thumbnails appear after few seconds)
  • Hot Images: Viral images need extra CDN capacity (auto-scale)
  • Storage Costs: How to reduce? (Compression, format conversion to WebP)

Best Practices

  • Use image CDN (CloudFront, Cloudflare, Fastly)
  • Generate thumbnails asynchronously (don't block upload)
  • Store metadata separately from image data
  • Implement retry logic for failed processing
  • Use WebP format for 25-35% size reduction
  • Add watermarks for copyright protection

Performance Metrics

  • Upload Time: <200ms for upload initiation
  • Processing Time: <5 seconds for thumbnail generation
  • CDN Hit Ratio: >95% (most requests never hit origin)
  • Availability: 99.99% (4 nines = 52 minutes downtime/year)

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

lessons.title: Design Twitter/Social Feed
lessons.description: Design a social media feed with tweet posting, timeline generation, and fan-out strategies
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Design Twitter/Social Feed - Design a social media feed with tweet posting, timeline generation, and fan-out strategies
  • Caching usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Consistency usage demonstrated through practical examples

System Design: Twitter Social Feed

Overview

Design a social media feed with tweet posting, timeline generation, and fan-out strategies

This lesson focuses on concepts frequently tested in FAANG interviews. Understanding this topic is crucial for technical interview success.

Introduction

Twitter processes 400M+ tweets daily with instant delivery to millions of followers. The core challenge is timeline generation: fan-out on write vs fan-out on read strategies.

Requirements

  • Functional: Post tweet (280 chars), follow users, view timeline, like/retweet
  • Non-Functional: 400M tweets/day, <5 seconds delivery, 330M users, 99.9% availability
  • Scale: 400M tweets/day ÷ 86400s = 4600 tweets/second peak

Fan-Out Strategies

Fan-Out on Write (Push):
+ Fast reads (timeline pre-computed)
- Slow writes (must push to all followers)
- Wasted work if followers never read

Fan-Out on Read (Pull):
+ Fast writes (just store tweet)
+ No wasted work
- Slow reads (must aggregate on demand)

Hybrid Approach (Twitter's Solution):
- Fan-out on write for normal users (<10K followers)
- Fan-out on read for celebrities (>10K followers)
- Blend both at query time

Database Schema

Table: tweets
+-----------+------------------+
| id        | BIGINT PK        |
| user_id   | BIGINT           |
| text      | VARCHAR(280)     |
| created   | TIMESTAMP        |
| likes     | INT DEFAULT 0    |
| retweets  | INT DEFAULT 0    |
+-----------+------------------+

Table: follows
+-----------+------------------+
| follower  | BIGINT           |
| followee  | BIGINT           |
| created   | TIMESTAMP        |
+-----------+------------------+
PRIMARY KEY (follower, followee)

Table: timelines (materialized view)
+-----------+------------------+
| user_id   | BIGINT           |
| tweet_id  | BIGINT           |
| created   | TIMESTAMP        |
+-----------+------------------+
INDEX on (user_id, created DESC)

Timeline Generation Algorithm

// Hybrid fan-out approach
function getTimeline(userId):
    results = []

    // 1. Get from pre-computed timeline (fan-out on write)
    results += REDIS.ZRANGE("timeline:" + userId, 0, 800)

    // 2. Get celebrity tweets (fan-out on read)
    celebrities = getFollowedCelebrities(userId)
    for celeb in celebrities:
        tweets = DB.query("SELECT * FROM tweets WHERE user_id=? ORDER BY created DESC LIMIT 100", celeb)
        results += tweets

    // 3. Merge and sort by timestamp
    results.sort(by=timestamp, desc=true)

    return results[0:100]  // Top 100 tweets

Scaling Architecture

  • Write Path: Load balancer → Fanout service → Redis timelines
  • Read Path: Load balancer → Timeline service → Redis + DB
  • Cache: Redis for hot timelines (recent 800 tweets per user)
  • Database: MySQL sharded by user_id, read replicas

Real-World Examples

Twitter: Uses hybrid fan-out. Stores tweets in Manhattan (distributed DB). Timelines cached in Redis. Handles 6000 tweets/second.

Instagram: Similar feed architecture. Fan-out for <1M followers, pull for celebrities. 500M daily active users.

Facebook: News Feed uses ML ranking (EdgeRank algorithm). Considers recency, engagement, relationship strength.

Interview Tips

  • Discuss fan-out trade-offs (write vs read performance)
  • Handle celebrity users separately (Elon Musk has 100M+ followers)
  • Consider timeline staleness (5 second delay acceptable)
  • Estimate storage: 400M tweets × 280 chars × 365 days = 40 TB/year

Best Practices

  • Use hybrid fan-out for optimal performance
  • Cache timelines in Redis (ZSET sorted by timestamp)
  • Implement pagination for infinite scroll
  • Use Kafka for reliable tweet delivery
  • Add rate limiting (prevent tweet spam)

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

Further Learning:

Build on this foundation by exploring related concepts and practicing with real-world scenarios.

lessons.title: YouTube Streaming
lessons.description: Design YouTube's video streaming architecture with adaptive bitrate, CDN distribution, view count aggregation, and transcoding pipeline. Handle 500M+ views/day with low latency.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Uploaded: Learn System Design
Streaming 'Learn System Design' at 720p
Streaming 'Learn System Design' at 1080p
Total views: 2
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • YouTube Streaming - Design YouTube's video streaming architecture with adaptive bitrate, CDN distribution, view count aggregation, and trans
  • CDN usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Scalability usage demonstrated through practical examples

System Design: YouTube Streaming

Problem Overview

Design a video streaming platform like YouTube handling billions of videos, petabytes of storage, and millions of concurrent viewers. Must support upload, transcoding, CDN distribution, recommendations, and adaptive bitrate streaming. This is a common FAANG interview question testing your ability to design scalable distributed systems.

Key Requirements

  • Functional: Core features enabling primary use cases
  • Non-Functional: High availability (99.9%+), low latency, horizontal scalability
  • Scale: Handle millions of users, billions of requests daily

High-Level Architecture

Core Components:

  • API Gateway: Load balancing, rate limiting, authentication
  • Application Servers: Business logic tier, horizontally scalable
  • Database: SQL for ACID, NoSQL for scale (Cassandra/DynamoDB)
  • Cache Layer: Redis/Memcached for hot data
  • Message Queue: Kafka/RabbitMQ for async processing
  • CDN: CloudFront/Akamai for static content delivery

Implementation Strategy

class SystemService:
    def __init__(self):
        self.db = DatabaseConnection()
        self.cache = RedisCache()
        self.queue = MessageQueue()

    def handle_request(self, request):
        # 1. Check cache for hot data
        cached = self.cache.get(request.key)
        if cached:
            return cached

        # 2. Query database
        data = self.db.query(request.params)

        # 3. Update cache
        self.cache.set(request.key, data, ttl=3600)

        # 4. Async processing if needed
        if request.requires_processing:
            self.queue.publish('process_topic', data)

        return data

Database Design

-- Primary entities
CREATE TABLE entities (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id UUID NOT NULL,
    data JSONB,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NOW(),
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NOW()
);

CREATE INDEX idx_user_entities ON entities(user_id, created_at DESC);

-- Use partitioning for scale
CREATE TABLE entities_2024 PARTITION OF entities
FOR VALUES FROM ('2024-01-01') TO ('2025-01-01');

Real-World Examples

Google: Uses Bigtable, Spanner for global distribution, Colossus for storage.
Amazon: Microservices architecture, DynamoDB, S3, CloudFront CDN.
Netflix: 99% AWS infrastructure, Cassandra for metadata, S3 for content.
Facebook: TAO graph database, Memcached for caching, Haystack for photos.

Scalability Considerations

  • Horizontal Scaling: Add more servers behind load balancer
  • Database Sharding: Partition data by user_id or geographic region
  • Caching Strategy: Cache-aside pattern, write-through for consistency
  • Async Processing: Decouple heavy operations using message queues
  • CDN: Reduce latency and origin load for static assets

Common Pitfalls

  • Single point of failure - no redundancy in critical components
  • Not considering CAP theorem - can't have perfect consistency AND availability
  • Ignoring network partitions - design for failure scenarios
  • Premature optimization - start simple, scale based on metrics
  • Not monitoring - need observability into system health

Interview Tips

  • Clarify requirements first: scale, latency SLA, consistency needs
  • Start with high-level diagram, then drill into components
  • Discuss tradeoffs: consistency vs availability, SQL vs NoSQL, sync vs async
  • Mention specific technologies: Redis, Kafka, Cassandra, S3
  • Cover monitoring, alerting, disaster recovery, security

Time & Space Complexity

  • Read Operations: O(1) from cache, O(log n) from database with indexes
  • Write Operations: O(1) average, O(log n) for indexed columns
  • Storage: O(n) for n entities, optimize with compression and archiving
  • Network: Consider latency (10-100ms cross-region), optimize with CDN

Further Learning

Study system design patterns from "Designing Data-Intensive Applications" by Martin Kleppmann. Read engineering blogs from Google, Amazon, Netflix, Uber about their architecture evolution. Practice on platforms like LeetCode, Pramp, Exponent.

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Best Practices:

  • Write clean, readable code following language conventions
  • Test thoroughly with unit tests and edge cases
  • Handle errors gracefully
  • Consider performance for production use

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

lessons.title: Netflix CDN
lessons.description: Design Netflix's CDN architecture for video streaming with edge caching, origin servers, and cache invalidation strategies. Optimize for global content delivery and bandwidth costs.
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Netflix CDN - Design Netflix's CDN architecture for video streaming with edge caching, origin servers, and cache invalidation strategi
  • CDN usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Caching usage demonstrated through practical examples

System Design: Netflix CDN

Problem Overview

Design a Content Delivery Network for video streaming optimized for Netflix-scale traffic. Handle video caching, origin servers, edge locations, and efficient content distribution worldwide. This is a common FAANG interview question testing your ability to design scalable distributed systems.

Key Requirements

  • Functional: Core features enabling primary use cases
  • Non-Functional: High availability (99.9%+), low latency, horizontal scalability
  • Scale: Handle millions of users, billions of requests daily

High-Level Architecture

Core Components:

  • API Gateway: Load balancing, rate limiting, authentication
  • Application Servers: Business logic tier, horizontally scalable
  • Database: SQL for ACID, NoSQL for scale (Cassandra/DynamoDB)
  • Cache Layer: Redis/Memcached for hot data
  • Message Queue: Kafka/RabbitMQ for async processing
  • CDN: CloudFront/Akamai for static content delivery

Implementation Strategy

class SystemService:
    def __init__(self):
        self.db = DatabaseConnection()
        self.cache = RedisCache()
        self.queue = MessageQueue()

    def handle_request(self, request):
        # 1. Check cache for hot data
        cached = self.cache.get(request.key)
        if cached:
            return cached

        # 2. Query database

lessons.fullSolution:
// WhatsApp Messaging System
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    class Chat:
        List<str> messages = []

        void sendMessage(str user, str msg):
            str formatted = user + ": " + msg
            messages.append(formatted)
            print("Sent - " + formatted)

        void showMessages():
            print("Chat history:")
            for (str msg : messages):
                print("  " + msg)

    def main(str[] args):
        Chat chat = new Chat()
        chat.sendMessage("Alice", "Hello!")
        chat.sendMessage("Bob", "Hi Alice!")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Sent - Alice: Hello!
Sent - Bob: Hi Alice!

lessons.title: Web Crawler
lessons.description: Design a web crawler like Googlebot with URL frontier management, politeness policy, deduplication, and distributed crawling. Crawl billions of pages while respecting robots.txt.
lessons.fullSolution:
// Web Crawler
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    class Crawler:
        Set<str> visited = set()
        Queue<str> queue = deque()

        void crawl(str startUrl, maxPages):
            queue.append(startUrl)
            count = 0

            while (!queue == [] && count < maxPages):
                str url = queue.poll()
                if (visited.contains(url)) continue

                visited.append(url)
                print("Crawled: " + url)
                count++

                // Simulate finding links
                if (count < maxPages):
                    queue.append(url + "/page" + count)

    def main(str[] args):
        Crawler crawler = new Crawler()
        crawler.crawl("example.com", 3)
lessons.expectedOutput:
Crawled: example.com
Crawled: example.com/page1
Crawled: example.com/page2

lessons.description: Design a newsfeed ranking algorithm like Facebook with engagement scoring, edge rank, personalization, and A/B testing. Show relevant content to users based on interactions.
lessons.initialCode:
// Newsfeed Ranking Algorithm
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

// TODO: Complete the implementation

    class Post:
        str content
        likes, shares
        long timestamp

        Post(str content, likes, shares):
            this.content = content
            this.likes = likes
            this.shares = shares
            this.timestamp = System.currentTimeMillis()
            // TODO: Implement methods

        getScore():
            return likes * 1.0 + shares * 2.0

    class Feed:
        List<Post> posts = []

        void addPost(str content, likes, shares):
            posts.append(new Post(content, likes, shares))

        void showRanked():
            posts.sort((a, b) -> Double.compare(b.getScore(), a.getScore()))
            for (Post p : posts):
                print(p.content + " (score: " + p.getScore() + ")")

    def main(str[] args):
        Feed feed = new Feed()
        feed.addPost("Post A", 10, 2)
        feed.addPost("Post B", 5, 5)
        feed.addPost("Post C", 20, 1)
        feed.showRanked()

// Newsfeed Ranking Algorithm
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    class Post:
        str content
        likes, shares
        long timestamp

        Post(str content, likes, shares):
            this.content = content
            this.likes = likes
            this.shares = shares
            this.timestamp = System.currentTimeMillis()

        getScore():
            return likes * 1.0 + shares * 2.0

    class Feed:
        List<Post> posts = []

        void addPost(str content, likes, shares):
            posts.append(new Post(content, likes, shares))

        void showRanked():
            posts.sort((a, b) -> Double.compare(b.getScore(), a.getScore()))
            for (Post p : posts):
                print(p.content + " (score: " + p.getScore() + ")")

    def main(str[] args):
        Feed feed = new Feed()
        feed.addPost("Post A", 10, 2)
        feed.addPost("Post B", 5, 5)
        feed.addPost("Post C", 20, 1)
        feed.showRanked()
lessons.expectedOutput:
Post C (score: 22.0)
Post B (score: 15.0)
Post A (score: 14.0)
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Newsfeed Ranking - Design a newsfeed ranking algorithm like Facebook with engagement scoring, edge rank, personalization, and A/B testing.
  • Message Queues usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • System Design usage demonstrated through practical examples

System Design: Newsfeed Ranking

Problem Overview

Design a personalized newsfeed ranking algorithm like Facebook/Twitter, considering user interests, engagement, recency, and content relevance. This is a common FAANG interview question testing your ability to design scalable distributed systems.

Key Requirements

  • Functional: Core features enabling primary use cases
  • Non-Functional: High availability (99.9%+), low latency, horizontal scalability
  • Scale: Handle millions of users, billions of requests daily

High-Level Architecture

Core Components:

  • API Gateway: Load balancing, rate limiting, authentication
  • Application Servers: Business logic tier, horizontally scalable
  • Database: SQL for ACID, NoSQL for scale (Cassandra/DynamoDB)
  • Cache Layer: Redis/Memcached for hot data
  • Message Queue: Kafka/RabbitMQ for async processing
  • CDN: CloudFront/Akamai for static content delivery

Implementation Strategy

class SystemService:
    def __init__(self):
        self.db = DatabaseConnection()
        self.cache = RedisCache()
        self.queue = MessageQueue()

    def handle_request(self, request):
        # 1. Check cache for hot data
        cached = self.cache.get(request.key)
        if cached:
            return cached

        # 2. Query database
        data = self.db.query(request.params)

        # 3. Update cache
        self.cache.set(request.key, data, ttl=3600)

        # 4. Async processing if needed
        if request.requires_processing:
            self.queue.publish('process_topic', data)

        return data

Database Design

-- Primary entities
CREATE TABLE entities (
    id UUID PRIMARY KEY,
    user_id UUID NOT NULL,
    data JSONB,
    created_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NOW(),
    updated_at TIMESTAMP DEFAULT NOW()
);

CREATE INDEX idx_user_entities ON entities(user_id, created_at DESC);

-- Use partitioning for scale
CREATE TABLE entities_2024 PARTITION OF entities
FOR VALUES FROM ('2024-01-01') TO ('2025-01-01');

Real-World Examples

Google: Uses Bigtable, Spanner for global distribution, Colossus for storage.
Amazon: Microservices architecture, DynamoDB, S3, CloudFront CDN.
Netflix: 99% AWS infrastructure, Cassandra for metadata, S3 for content.
Facebook: TAO graph database, Memcached for caching, Haystack for photos.

Scalability Considerations

  • Horizontal Scaling: Add more servers behind load balancer
  • Database Sharding: Partition data by user_id or geographic region
  • Caching Strategy: Cache-aside pattern, write-through for consistency
  • Async Processing: Decouple heavy operations using message queues
  • CDN: Reduce latency and origin load for static assets

Common Pitfalls

  • Single point of failure - no redundancy in critical components
  • Not considering CAP theorem - can't have perfect consistency AND availability
  • Ignoring network partitions - design for failure scenarios
  • Premature optimization - start simple, scale based on metrics
  • Not monitoring - need observability into system health

Interview Tips

  • Clarify requirements first: scale, latency SLA, consistency needs
  • Start with high-level diagram, then drill into components
  • Discuss tradeoffs: consistency vs availability, SQL vs NoSQL, sync vs async
  • Mention specific technologies: Redis, Kafka, Cassandra, S3
  • Cover monitoring, alerting, disaster recovery, security

Time & Space Complexity

  • Read Operations: O(1) from cache, O(log n) from database with indexes
  • Write Operations: O(1) average, O(log n) for indexed columns
  • Storage: O(n) for n entities, optimize with compression and archiving
  • Network: Consider latency (10-100ms cross-region), optimize with CDN

Further Learning

Study system design patterns from "Designing Data-Intensive Applications" by Martin Kleppmann. Read engineering blogs from Google, Amazon, Netflix, Uber about their architecture evolution. Practice on platforms like LeetCode, Pramp, Exponent.

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

  • Handle errors gracefully
  • Consider performance for production use

        tax = 0.10

lessons.title: Two Pointers - Array Pair Sum
lessons.description: Find two numbers in sorted array that sum to target using two pointers (O(n) time)
lessons.initialCode:
# Two Pointers: Find pair that sums to target
# TODO: Implement using two pointers

def two_sum(nums, target):
    # TODO: Use two pointers from both ends
    pass

nums = [2, 7, 11, 15]
target = 9
result = two_sum(nums, target)
print(result)
lessons.fullSolution:
def two_sum(nums, target):
    left, right = 0, len(nums) - 1

    while left < right:
        current_sum = nums[left] + nums[right]
        if current_sum == target:
            return [left, right]
        elif current_sum < target:
            left += 1
        else:
            right -= 1

    return [-1, -1]

nums1 = [2, 7, 11, 15]
print("Input: [2,7,11,15], target: 9")
print(f"Output: {two_sum(nums1, 9)}")

nums2 = [1, 2, 3, 4, 6]
print("Input: [1,2,3,4,6], target: 6")
print(f"Output: {two_sum(nums2, 6)}")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Input: [2,7,11,15], target: 9
Output: [0, 1]
Input: [1,2,3,4,6], target: 6
Output: [1, 3]

lessons.title: Sliding Window - Maximum Sum Subarray
lessons.description: Find maximum sum of k consecutive elements using sliding window technique Essential concept for FAANG-level technical interviews.
lessons.tutorial:
Algorithm Pattern: Sliding Window

Overview

Find maximum sum of k consecutive elements using sliding window technique Essential concept for FAANG-level technical interviews.

This lesson focuses on concepts frequently tested in FAANG interviews. Understanding this topic is crucial for technical interview success.

Introduction

The sliding window technique optimizes problems involving contiguous subarrays or substrings. Instead of recalculating from scratch for each position (O(n×k)), we maintain a window and slide it efficiently (O(n)).

Key Concepts

  • Fixed Window: Window size is constant (this problem)
  • Variable Window: Window size changes based on condition
  • Time Optimization: O(n×k) → O(n)
  • Space Complexity: O(1) - only store window sum

Algorithm Steps

1. Calculate sum of first k elements (initialize window)
2. Set maxSum = windowSum
3. Slide window right:
   - Remove leftmost element (arr[i-k])
   - Add new rightmost element (arr[i])
   - Update maxSum if current sum is larger
4. Return maxSum

Code Walkthrough

Array: [2, 1, 5, 1, 3, 2], k=3

Initial window: [2, 1, 5] → sum = 8

Slide 1: Remove 2, add 1
Window: [1, 5, 1] → sum = 7

Slide 2: Remove 1, add 3
Window: [5, 1, 3] → sum = 9 ← MAX

Slide 3: Remove 5, add 2
Window: [1, 3, 2] → sum = 6

Result: 9

Pattern Variations

  • Fixed Window: Max sum, average, product (this problem)
  • Variable Window: Longest substring without repeating chars, min window substring
  • Two Pointer Variation: Subarray sum equals K, longest subarray with sum ≤ K

Real-World Applications

Network Traffic Analysis: Calculate moving average of packet sizes over time window.

Stock Trading: Find best N consecutive days for maximum profit.

Data Stream Processing: Real-time metrics over sliding time windows (last 5 minutes).

Interview Companies

  • Amazon: "Maximum Average Subarray" - direct sliding window
  • Microsoft: "Minimum Size Subarray Sum" - variable window
  • Bloomberg: "Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters"
  • Google: "Subarrays with K Different Integers" - advanced sliding window

Time Complexity

  • Brute Force: O(n×k) - recalculate sum for each position
  • Sliding Window: O(n) - single pass through array
  • Space: O(1) - only store window sum and max

Common Mistakes

  • Forgetting to handle edge case (arr.length < k)
  • Off-by-one errors in window boundaries
  • Not initializing maxSum correctly (use first window sum, not 0)
  • Calculating sum from scratch each iteration (defeats purpose)

Related Problems

Master sliding window to solve: Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters, Minimum Window Substring, Permutation in String, Fruit Into Baskets, and Max Consecutive Ones III.

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Best Practices:

  • Write clean, readable code following language conventions
  • Test thoroughly with unit tests and edge cases
  • Handle errors gracefully
  • Consider performance for production use

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

lessons.title: Trie Word Search
lessons.description: Implement trie (prefix tree) for word search with insert, search, and startsWith operations. Optimize for prefix matching and autocomplete use cases.
lessons.fullSolution:
// Trie for Word Search
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    class TrieNode:
        Map<Character, TrieNode> children = {}
        isWord = false

    class Trie:
        TrieNode root = new TrieNode()

        void insert(str word):
            TrieNode node = root
            for (char c : word):
                node.children.putIfAbsent(c, new TrieNode())
                node = node.children[c)

            node.isWord = true

        search(str word):
            TrieNode node = root
            for (char c : word):
                if (!node.children in c)) return false
                node = node.children[c)

            return node.isWord

        startsWith(str prefix):
            TrieNode node = root
            for (char c : prefix):
                if (!node.children in c)) return false
                node = node.children[c)

            return true

    def main(str[] args):
        Trie trie = new Trie()
        trie.insert("apple")
        trie.insert("app")

        print("Search 'app': " + trie.search("app"))
        print("Search 'apple': " + trie.search("apple"))
        print("Prefix 'ap': " + trie.startsWith("ap"))
lessons.expectedOutput:
Search 'app': true
Search 'apple': true
Prefix 'ap': true

lessons.title: Dijkstra Algorithm
lessons.description: Implement Dijkstra's shortest path algorithm using priority queue. Find shortest paths from source to all vertices in weighted graph with non-negative edges.
lessons.fullSolution:
// Dijkstra's Shortest Path
from typing import List, Dict, Set
from collections import deque
import heapq

    public static List[int] dijkstra(List[int][] graph, start):
        n = graph.length
        List[int] dist = new int[n]
        Arrays.fill(dist, Integer.MAX_VALUE)
        dist[start] = 0

        PriorityQueue<List[int]> pq = new PriorityQueue<>((a, b) -> a[1] - b[1])
        pq.offer(new List[int]{start, 0})

        while (!pq == []):
            List[int] current = pq.poll()
            node = current[0]
            d = current[1]

            if (d > dist[node]) continue

            for (neighbor = 0 neighbor < n neighbor++):
                if (graph[node][neighbor] > 0):
                    newDist = dist[node] + graph[node][neighbor]
                    if (newDist < dist[neighbor]):
                        dist[neighbor] = newDist
                        pq.offer(new List[int]{neighbor, newDist})

        return dist

    def main(str[] args):
        List[int][] graph =:
            {0, 4, 0, 0, 0},
            {4, 0, 8, 0, 0},
            {0, 8, 0, 7, 9},
            {0, 0, 7, 0, 10},
            {0, 0, 9, 10, 0}

        List[int] distances = dijkstra(graph, 0)
        print("Distances from node 0: " + Arrays.tostr(distances))
lessons.tutorial:
Algorithm: Dijkstra Algorithm

Overview

Shortest path This algorithm is frequently asked in FAANG interviews and is essential for solving Shortest path. Mastering this technique will help you tackle a wide range of coding challenges.

Key Concepts

  • Core algorithmic principle and when to apply it
  • Common patterns and variations of the technique
  • Edge cases and boundary conditions to consider
  • Optimization strategies for time and space complexity

Implementation Approach

The key insight is to recognize when this algorithm applies. Look for these signals: Shortest path characteristics, specific input patterns, and optimization requirements. Always start by understanding the problem constraints.

Code Example

def solve(input_data):
    # Step 1: Initialize data structures
    result = []

    # Step 2: Process input with algorithm
    # Apply core technique here

    # Step 3: Handle edge cases
    if not input_data:
        return []

    # Step 4: Return result
    return result

# Example usage
test_input = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
output = solve(test_input)
print(f"Result: {output}")

Real-World Applications

Google: Search algorithms, graph processing, ranking systems.
Facebook: Social graph traversal, friend recommendations, news feed ranking.
Amazon: Product recommendations, inventory optimization, route planning.
Netflix: Content recommendation, A/B testing, personalization algorithms.

Best Practices

  • Always clarify input constraints (size, range, duplicates allowed?)
  • Start with brute force, then optimize iteratively
  • Draw examples and trace through algorithm manually first
  • Handle edge cases: empty input, single element, all same values
  • Test with small examples before submitting
  • Consider space-time tradeoffs

Common Pitfalls

  • Off-by-one errors in array bounds and loop conditions
  • Not handling duplicate values correctly
  • Integer overflow for large inputs (use long/bigint)
  • Not considering negative numbers or zero
  • Forgetting to sort input when algorithm requires it

Interview Tips

  • Explain your thought process before coding
  • Discuss time/space complexity upfront
  • Mention alternative approaches and tradeoffs
  • Test your code with examples (including edge cases)
  • Optimize only after getting working solution
  • Ask clarifying questions about input constraints

Time & Space Complexity

  • Time Complexity: O((V+E) log V) time
  • Space Complexity: O(V) space
  • Optimization: Consider trading space for time or vice versa based on constraints

lessons.title: SQL Injection Prevention
lessons.description: Learn to prevent SQL injection attacks using parameterized queries and prepared statements
lessons.initialCode:
# SQL Injection Prevention
# VULNERABLE: String formatting
# SAFE: Parameterized queries

def unsafe_query(username):
    # TODO: Show vulnerable query
    pass

def safe_query(username):
    # TODO: Use parameterized query (? or %s)
    pass

attack = "admin' OR '1'='1"
print("UNSAFE:", unsafe_query(attack))
print("SAFE:", safe_query(attack))
lessons.fullSolution:
def unsafe_query(username):
    return f"SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='{username}'"
    # Attack: username = "admin' OR '1'='1"

def safe_query(username):
    # Use parameterized query with ? or %s placeholder
    return "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?"
    # Database driver escapes the parameter

attack = "admin' OR '1'='1"

print("SQL Injection Prevention Demo")
print("=" * 40)
print()
print("UNSAFE Query:")
print(unsafe_query(attack))
print("Result: Bypasses authentication!")
print()
print("SAFE Query:")
print(safe_query("admin"))
print(f"Parameter: {attack}")
print("Result: Treats input as literal string")
lessons.expectedOutput:
SQL Injection Prevention Demo
========================================

UNSAFE Query:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='admin' OR '1'='1'
Result: Bypasses authentication!

SAFE Query:
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?
Parameter: admin' OR '1'='1
Result: Treats input as literal string
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • SQL Injection Prevention - Learn to prevent SQL injection attacks using parameterized queries and prepared statements
  • Database usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Databases usage demonstrated through practical examples

Security: SQL Injection Prevention

Overview

Learn to prevent SQL injection attacks using parameterized queries and prepared statements

This lesson focuses on concepts frequently tested in FAANG interviews. Understanding this topic is crucial for technical interview success.

Introduction

SQL Injection is #3 in OWASP Top 10. Attackers inject malicious SQL through user inputs to steal data, bypass authentication, or delete databases. Prevention requires parameterized queries.

Attack Example

// VULNERABLE CODE
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='" + username + "'";

// ATTACK INPUT
username = "admin' OR '1'='1"

// RESULTING QUERY (bypasses authentication!)
SELECT * FROM users WHERE username='admin' OR '1'='1'

Safe Implementation

// SAFE CODE (Java)
String query = "SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?";
PreparedStatement pstmt = conn.prepareStatement(query);
pstmt.setString(1, username);

// SAFE CODE (Python)
cursor.execute("SELECT * FROM users WHERE username=?", (username,))

Why Parameterized Queries Work

  • Database driver separates SQL code from data
  • Parameters are escaped automatically
  • Single quotes in input become literal characters
  • No way for attacker to break out of string context

Real-World Breaches

Heartland Payment (2008): SQL injection stole 130M credit cards. Cost: $140M in settlements.

Sony Pictures (2011): SQL injection exposed 1M accounts. Class action lawsuit.

Bobby Tables (xkcd): "Robert'); DROP TABLE students;--" famous comic.

Prevention Techniques

  • PreparedStatement (Java): ALWAYS use for dynamic queries
  • Parameterized queries: Use ? or :name placeholders
  • ORM safety: Hibernate/JPA escape automatically
  • Input validation: Whitelist allowed characters
  • Least privilege: Database user with minimal permissions

Best Practices

  • Never concatenate user input into SQL strings
  • Use ORM frameworks (Hibernate, SQLAlchemy) when possible
  • Whitelist validation for special cases (table names, ORDER BY)
  • Don't expose SQL errors to users (information leakage)
  • Run database with least privilege (read-only where possible)

Interview Tips

  • Explain difference between prepared statements and string concatenation
  • Discuss OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities
  • Mention defense in depth (parameterized queries + input validation + least privilege)
  • Know how to use PreparedStatement in Java, parameterized queries in Python

Common Pitfalls

  • Not testing edge cases like empty input, null values, or boundary conditions
  • Forgetting to handle error conditions gracefully

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

Further Learning:

Build on this foundation by exploring related concepts and practicing with real-world scenarios.

Security: XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) Defense

Overview

Prevent XSS attacks with output encoding, Content Security Policy, and input sanitization

This lesson focuses on concepts frequently tested in FAANG interviews. Understanding this topic is crucial for technical interview success.

Introduction

XSS is #7 in OWASP Top 10. Attackers inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users. Can steal cookies, session tokens, or redirect to phishing sites. Prevention requires output encoding and Content Security Policy.

Types of XSS

  • Stored XSS: Malicious script stored in database (e.g., comment with " // If displayed without escaping:
    Check this out!
    // Result: All users viewing this comment send their cookies to attacker!

    Defense #1: Output Encoding

    // Always escape HTML special characters
function escapeHtml(text) {
    return text
        .replace(/&/g, "&")   // & → &
        .replace(//g, ">")    // > → >
        .replace(/"/g, """)  // " → "
        .replace(/'/g, "'")  // ' → '
        .replace(/\//g, "/");// / → /
}

// Safe output:
""
becomes
"<script>alert('XSS')</script>"

    Defense #2: Content Security Policy (CSP)

    // HTTP Header to prevent inline scripts
Content-Security-Policy:
  default-src 'self';
  script-src 'self' https://trusted-cdn.com;
  style-src 'self' 'unsafe-inline';
  img-src 'self' data:;

// This blocks:
- Inline

lessons.tutorial:
Security: CSRF Tokens

Overview

Prevent Cross-Site Request Forgery attacks using synchronizer tokens Security is critical for protecting user data, preventing breaches, and maintaining trust. This concept is essential for any production system handling sensitive information.

Key Concepts

  • Understanding the security threat and attack vectors
  • Defense mechanisms and prevention strategies
  • Industry standards and compliance requirements (OWASP, PCI-DSS)
  • Detection and monitoring for security incidents

Implementation Approach

Security must be built into the system from day one, not added as an afterthought. Follow the principle of defense in depth with multiple layers of protection. Regularly audit and update security measures.

Code Example

# Security implementation example
import hashlib
import secrets

class SecurityService:
    def generate_token(self):
        # Cryptographically secure random token
        return secrets.token_urlsafe(32)

    def hash_password(self, password):
        # Use bcrypt or Argon2 in production
        salt = secrets.token_bytes(32)
        hashed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)
        return salt + hashed

    def verify_password(self, password, stored_hash):
        salt = stored_hash[:32]
        stored_pwd = stored_hash[32:]
        computed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)
        return secrets.compare_digest(stored_pwd, computed)

# Usage
security = SecurityService()
token = security.generate_token()
hashed_pwd = security.hash_password("user_password")
is_valid = security.verify_password("user_password", hashed_pwd)

Real-World Examples

Google: Enforces HTTPS everywhere, uses security keys for 2FA, runs Project Zero.
AWS: IAM for access control, KMS for encryption, automated security patching.
GitHub: Dependabot for vulnerability scanning, signed commits, security advisories.
Stripe: PCI-DSS Level 1 compliant, token-based payments, rate limiting.

Best Practices

  • Never store passwords in plain text - always hash with salt
  • Use parameterized queries to prevent SQL injection
  • Implement rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks
  • Keep dependencies updated to patch known vulnerabilities
  • Enable security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS)
  • Use HTTPS/TLS for all sensitive data transmission
  • Implement proper authentication and authorization
  • Log security events for audit and incident response

Common Pitfalls

  • Using weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms (MD5, SHA1)
  • Hardcoding secrets in source code or configuration files
  • Insufficient input validation allowing injection attacks
  • Missing rate limiting enabling brute force attacks
  • Not encrypting sensitive data at rest and in transit
  • Overly permissive CORS settings exposing APIs

Interview Tips

  • Discuss security threats: XSS, CSRF, SQL injection, DDoS
  • Explain defense mechanisms: input validation, output encoding, rate limiting
  • Mention compliance: GDPR, HIPAA, PCI-DSS requirements
  • Cover authentication: OAuth2, JWT, session management
  • Address encryption: TLS, at-rest encryption, key management
  • Discuss incident response and security monitoring

Security Checklist

  • Authentication: Multi-factor, password complexity, session timeout
  • Authorization: Role-based access control, principle of least privilege
  • Data Protection: Encryption at rest and in transit, secure backups
  • Input/Output: Validate input, encode output, parameterized queries
  • Monitoring: Security logs, intrusion detection, anomaly detection

Further Learning

Study OWASP Top 10 security risks. Practice on HackTheBox and OWASP WebGoat. Read security blogs from Google Project Zero, Krebs on Security. Get certified in security (CEH, CISSP). Follow responsible disclosure when finding vulnerabilities.

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

class SecurityService:
    def generate_token(self):

        return secrets.compare_digest(stored_pwd, computed)

# Usage
security = SecurityService()
token = security.generate_token()
hashed_pwd = security.hash_password("user_password")
is_valid = security.verify_password("user_password", hashed_pwd)

Real-World Examples

Google: Enforces HTTPS everywhere, uses security keys for 2FA, runs Project Zero.
AWS: IAM for access control, KMS for encryption, automated security patching.
GitHub: Dependabot for vulnerability scanning, signed commits, security advisories.
Stripe: PCI-DSS Level 1 compliant, token-based payments, rate limiting.

Best Practices

  • Never store passwords in plain text - always hash with salt
  • Use parameterized queries to prevent SQL injection
  • Implement rate limiting to prevent brute force attacks
  • Keep dependencies updated to patch known vulnerabilities
  • Enable security headers (CSP, X-Frame-Options, HSTS)
  • Use HTTPS/TLS for all sensitive data transmission
  • Implement proper authentication and authorization
  • Log security events for audit and incident response

Common Pitfalls

  • Using weak or outdated cryptographic algorithms (MD5, SHA1)
  • Hardcoding secrets in source code or configuration files
  • Insufficient input validation allowing injection attacks
  • Missing rate limiting enabling brute force attacks
  • Not encrypting sensitive data at rest and in transit
  • Overly permissive CORS settings exposing APIs

Interview Tips

  • Discuss security threats: XSS, CSRF, SQL injection, DDoS
  • Explain defense mechanisms: input validation, output encoding, rate limiting
  • Mention compliance: GDPR, HIPAA, PCI-DSS requirements
  • Cover authentication: OAuth2, JWT, session management
  • Address encryption: TLS, at-rest encryption, key management
  • Discuss incident response and security monitoring

Security Checklist

  • Authentication: Multi-factor, password complexity, session timeout
  • Authorization: Role-based access control, principle of least privilege
  • Data Protection: Encryption at rest and in transit, secure backups
  • Input/Output: Validate input, encode output, parameterized queries
  • Monitoring: Security logs, intrusion detection, anomaly detection

Further Learning

Study OWASP Top 10 security risks. Practice on HackTheBox and OWASP WebGoat. Read security blogs from Google Project Zero, Krebs on Security. Get certified in security (CEH, CISSP). Follow responsible disclosure when finding vulnerabilities.

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Code Example

# Security implementation example
import hashlib
import secrets

class SecurityService:
    def generate_token(self):
        # Cryptographically secure random token
        return secrets.token_urlsafe(32)

    def hash_password(self, password):
        # Use bcrypt or Argon2 in production
        salt = secrets.token_bytes(32)
        hashed = hashlib.pbkdf2_hmac('sha256', password.encode(), salt, 100000)

lessons.title: Code Review Best Practices
lessons.description: Learn to conduct effective code reviews with constructive feedback and collaboration
lessons.fullSolution:
# ORIGINAL (with issues):
def process_data_old(data):
    for i in range(len(data)):
        item=data[i]
        if item!=None:
            print(item.upper())

# IMPROVED (after code review):
def process_data(data):
    if not data:
        return

    for item in data:        # Pythonic iteration
        if item is not None:  # Use 'is not None'
            print(item.upper())

data = ["apple", "banana", None, "cherry"]

print("Original:")
process_data_old(data)

print("\nImproved:")
process_data(data)

print("\nReview Comments:")
print("1. Use direct iteration instead of range(len())")
print("2. Use 'is not None' instead of '!=None'")
print("3. Add spacing around operators")
print("4. Add input validation")
lessons.expectedOutput:
Original:
APPLE
BANANA
CHERRY

Improved:
APPLE
BANANA
CHERRY

Review Comments:
1. Use enhanced for loop (more readable)
2. Add spacing around operators
3. Add null check on input list
lessons.tutorial:
Professional Skills: Code Review

Overview

Best practices for giving and receiving constructive code feedback These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Code Review Checklist

# Code Review Checklist
[] Functionality: Does the code do what it's supposed to?
[] Tests: Are there unit tests? Do they cover edge cases?
[] Readability: Is the code easy to understand?
[] Performance: Any obvious performance issues?
[] Security: Any security vulnerabilities?
[] Error Handling: Are errors handled gracefully?
[] Documentation: Are complex parts documented?
[] Style: Does it follow team conventions?

# Example Good Review Comment:
"Nice work! The logic is clear. One suggestion: consider adding
a null check on line 45 before calling user.getName() to prevent
NullPointerException. Also, the function could benefit from a
doc comment explaining the expected input format."

Best Practices

  • Be proactive in seeking opportunities to practice this skill
  • Learn from mistakes and iterate on your approach
  • Seek mentorship from more experienced professionals
  • Document lessons learned for future reference
  • Share knowledge with teammates to strengthen team capability
  • Continuously refine your process based on feedback

Real-World Applications

Google: Code review culture, design docs, tech talks, 20% time.
Amazon: PR/FAQ documents, working backwards, two-pizza teams.
Facebook: Bootcamp training, move fast philosophy, hackathons.
Netflix: Freedom and responsibility, context not control, high talent density.

Common Pitfalls

  • Not investing time to develop soft skills (focusing only on technical)
  • Being overly critical or defensive in feedback situations
  • Poor communication leading to misunderstandings and conflicts
  • Not seeking help when stuck, wasting time on blockers
  • Ignoring team dynamics and only focusing on individual contribution

Career Impact

Soft skills differentiate senior engineers from junior ones. While technical skills get you in the door, soft skills determine how far you progress. Engineers who master communication, collaboration, and leadership advance faster and have greater impact on their organizations.

Interview Tips

  • Prepare stories demonstrating this skill using STAR method (Situation, Task, Action, Result)
  • Highlight collaboration and teamwork in your examples
  • Show growth mindset - discuss how you learned from challenges
  • Ask thoughtful questions about team culture and processes
  • Demonstrate empathy and emotional intelligence

Development Roadmap

  • Beginner: Shadow experienced team members, learn the basics
  • Intermediate: Practice independently, seek regular feedback
  • Advanced: Mentor others, establish team best practices
  • Expert: Drive org-wide initiatives, thought leadership

Further Learning

Read "The Pragmatic Programmer", "Clean Code", "Crucial Conversations". Take courses on communication, leadership, project management. Join communities like Dev.to, Hacker News. Present at meetups and conferences. Find a mentor who excels in these areas.

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

lessons.title: Writing Technical Documentation
lessons.description: Create clear, comprehensive technical documentation including README, API docs, and architecture guides
lessons.expectedOutput:
'racecar': true
'A man, a plan, a canal: Panama': true
'hello': false
lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Writing Technical Documentation - Create clear, comprehensive technical documentation including README, API docs, and architecture guides
  • Career usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Communication usage demonstrated through practical examples

Soft Skills: Writing Technical Documentation

Introduction

Good documentation is as important as good code. It helps teammates understand your work, reduces onboarding time, and serves as reference for future maintenance. Poor documentation costs companies millions in lost productivity.

Overview

Create clear, comprehensive technical documentation including README, API docs, and architecture guides

This FAANG-level lesson covers concepts frequently tested in top-tier technical interviews.

Types of Documentation

  • README: Project overview, setup instructions, usage examples
  • API Documentation: Function/method signatures, parameters, return values
  • Architecture Docs: System design, component relationships, data flow
  • Code Comments: Inline explanations for complex logic
  • Runbooks: Operational procedures, troubleshooting guides

README Structure

# Project Name

Brief description (1-2 sentences)

## Features
- Feature 1
- Feature 2

## Installation
```bash
npm install
```

## Usage
```javascript
const result = myFunction();
```

## API Reference
See [API.md](API.md)

## Contributing
See [CONTRIBUTING.md](CONTRIBUTING.md)

## License
MIT

Javadoc Best Practices

/**
 * Brief one-line summary.
 *
 * 
Detailed description with examples, constraints,
 * and edge cases. Use HTML tags for formatting.
 *
 * 
{@code
 * // Code example
 * int result = myMethod(5);
 * }

 *
 * @param name parameter description
 * @return return value description
 * @throws ExceptionType when this is thrown
 * @see RelatedClass#relatedMethod()
 * @since 1.0
 */

Writing Guidelines

  • Audience-Aware: Write for your target reader (junior dev, ops team, customer)
  • Examples First: Show usage before explaining internals
  • Be Concise: Remove unnecessary words, prefer bullet points
  • Keep Updated: Update docs when code changes (CI check)
  • Use Diagrams: Architecture diagrams, sequence diagrams, flowcharts

Real-World Examples

Stripe API Docs: Gold standard. Clear examples, error codes, SDKs in multiple languages. Developers love Stripe partly due to excellent docs.

Kubernetes Docs: Complex system made accessible. Tutorials, concepts, reference guides organized by user journey.

React Docs: Interactive examples, clear API reference, troubleshooting guides.

Documentation Tools

  • Javadoc: Auto-generate HTML from Java comments
  • Sphinx: Python documentation generator
  • Swagger/OpenAPI: API documentation from specs
  • Docusaurus: Facebook's documentation site generator
  • MkDocs: Markdown-based documentation

Common Mistakes

  • Obvious Comments: "// increment i" for i++ (waste of space)
  • Outdated Docs: Worse than no docs (misleads developers)
  • No Examples: Theory without practice is hard to understand
  • Too Technical: Assuming too much knowledge from reader
  • Missing Context: Not explaining "why", only "what"

Interview Relevance

  • Google: Emphasizes clear communication. May ask about documentation strategy
  • Amazon: Leadership principle "Insist on Highest Standards" includes docs
  • Microsoft: Strong documentation culture (Office, Azure, VS Code)

Career Impact

Senior engineers are evaluated on documentation quality. Staff/Principal engineers write design docs, RFCs, and architecture guides. Clear writing accelerates promotion.

Best Practices Checklist

  • ✅ README with quick start guide
  • ✅ API docs with examples
  • ✅ Architecture diagram (C4 model)
  • ✅ Troubleshooting section
  • ✅ Contributing guidelines
  • ✅ Changelog (semantic versioning)
  • ✅ License file

Practical Applications:

This technique is used extensively in professional software development for building robust, maintainable applications.

Key Takeaways:

  • Understand the core syntax and usage patterns
  • Know when to apply this technique
  • Practice with variations to build mastery

Further Learning:

Build on this foundation by exploring related concepts and practicing with real-world scenarios.

lessons.title: Debugging Strategies
lessons.description: Master debugging strategies: use debugger breakpoints, add logging, reproduce bugs, use binary search to isolate issues, and read stack traces effectively.
lessons.expectedOutput:
Discount for $100 at 15%: $15.0
Discount for $10 at 15%: $1.5
Bug fixed: Now returns 1.5 instead of 1 for $10 at 15%
lessons.tutorial:
Professional Skills: Debugging

Overview

Systematic approaches to finding and fixing bugs efficiently These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Debugging Example

// PROBLEM: Function returns wrong result
public int calculateDiscount(int price, int percent) {{
    return price * percent / 100;  // Bug: integer division
}}

// DEBUGGING STEPS:
// 1. Add print statements
System.out.println("price: " + price + ", percent: " + percent);
System.out.println("result: " + (price * percent / 100));

// 2. Use debugger breakpoint here
int discount = price * percent / 100;  // <-- breakpoint
return discount;

// 3. Test with specific values
calculateDiscount(100, 15);  // Expected: 15, Got: 15 ✓
calculateDiscount(10, 15);   // Expected: 1.5, Got: 1 ✗

// SOLUTION: Use floating point
public double calculateDiscount(int price, int percent) {{
    return price * percent / 100.0;  // Fixed: 100.0 ensures float division
}}

  • Be proactive in seeking opportunities to practice this skill
  • Learn from mistakes and iterate on your approach

git pull origin main

# After code review, merge and cleanup

git pull origin main
git branch -d feature/add-user-auth

# Hotfix Workflow
git checkout main
git checkout -b hotfix/critical-security-patch
# Fix bug, commit, push

# Emergency merge after quick review

Professional Skills: Performance Profiling

Overview

Tools and techniques for identifying performance bottlenecks These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Profiling Example

// Slow function (before profiling)
public List<User> getUsersWithOrders() {{
    List<User> users = userRepository.findAll();
    for (User user : users) {{
        user.setOrders(orderRepository.findByUserId(user.getId())); // N+1 query!
    }}
    return users;
}}

// After profiling with JProfiler/YourKit:
// - Identified N+1 query problem
// - Database calls: 1001 (1 for users + 1000 for each user's orders)
// - Time: 5000ms

// Optimized (after profiling)
public List<User> getUsersWithOrders() {{
    List<User> users = userRepository.findAllWithOrders(); // Single JOIN query
    return users;
}}

// After optimization:
// - Database calls: 1
// - Time: 50ms
// - 100x faster!

Professional Skills: Stack Traces

Overview

Reading and interpreting stack traces to diagnose errors These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals
  • Metrics for measuring effectiveness and improvement

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Reading Stack Traces

// Exception Stack Trace Example
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.NullPointerException
    at com.example.UserService.getEmail(UserService.java:42)
    at com.example.EmailSender.send(EmailSender.java:18)
    at com.example.Main.main(Main.java:12)

// How to read:
// 1. Start from TOP: NullPointerException
// 2. First line is WHERE: UserService.java line 42
// 3. Follow call chain: Main -> EmailSender -> UserService
// 4. Check line 42 in UserService.java

// Code at UserService.java:42
public String getEmail(User user) {{
    return user.getEmail();  // <-- line 42: user is null!
}}

// Fix: Add null check
public String getEmail(User user) {{
    if (user == null) {{
        throw new IllegalArgumentException("User cannot be null");
    }}
    return user.getEmail();
}}

  • Be proactive in seeking opportunities to practice this skill

Overview

Estimating complexity and effort for agile planning These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical
  • Tools and techniques used by industry professionals

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Story Point Estimation

# Story Point Scale (Fibonacci)
1 point  = 1-2 hours   (trivial: update button text)
2 points = 2-4 hours   (simple: add form validation)
3 points = 4-8 hours   (moderate: add new API endpoint)
5 points = 1-2 days    (complex: integrate payment gateway)
8 points = 2-3 days    (very complex: build analytics dashboard)
13 points = 1 week+    (epic: redesign authentication system)

# Estimation Meeting Example
Product Owner: "As a user, I want to export my data to PDF"

Team Discussion:
- Similar to CSV export we did? (That was 3 points)
- Need PDF library (+1 complexity)
- Formatting layout (+1 complexity)
- Testing with large datasets (+1 complexity)

Consensus: 5 points

# Velocity Tracking
Sprint 1: Committed 20 points, Completed 18 points
Sprint 2: Committed 22 points, Completed 20 points
Sprint 3: Committed 20 points, Completed 21 points
Average Velocity: 20 points per sprint

Professional Skills: Agile/Scrum

Overview

Agile methodologies, sprints, standups, retrospectives These soft skills are just as important as technical ability for career success. Top engineers excel not just at coding, but also at collaboration, communication, and delivering impact in team environments.

Key Concepts

  • Core principles and framework for this skill
  • Common scenarios where this skill is critical

Practical Approach

Developing this skill requires practice and iteration. Start by observing how senior engineers approach similar situations. Apply the techniques in low-stakes environments first, then gradually increase complexity. Seek feedback regularly and adjust your approach.

Agile/Scrum Ceremonies

# Sprint Planning (Monday 9am, 2 hours)
Goal: Plan next 2-week sprint
- Review product backlog
- Select stories for sprint
- Break down stories into tasks
- Commit to sprint goal

# Daily Standup (Every day 9:30am, 15 min)
Each team member answers:
1. What did I do yesterday?
2. What will I do today?
3. Any blockers?

Example:
"Yesterday: Finished user auth API
 Today: Starting frontend integration
 Blockers: Need design mockups from UX team"

# Sprint Review (Friday 2pm, 1 hour)
- Demo completed features
- Get stakeholder feedback
- Accept/reject stories

# Sprint Retrospective (Friday 3pm, 1 hour)
What went well?
- Good code reviews
- Fast bug fixes

What can improve?
- Better documentation
- Reduce meeting times

Action items:
[] Write setup guide in README
[] Move standup to Slack async

  • Be proactive in seeking opportunities to practice this skill

Hi [Stakeholder Name],

Progress This Week:
✓ Completed JWT token implementation

Upcoming Next Week:
- Finish email verification
- Add two-factor authentication
- Begin security testing

Risks/Blockers:

- May need 2 extra days if review has feedback

Metrics:
- Sprint velocity: On track (18/20 points)
- Test coverage: 85%
- Bug count: 2 (both low priority)

Questions? Happy to discuss in tomorrow's standup.

Best,
[Your Name]

lessons.tutorial:
Overview

This capstone project synthesizes everything you've learned into a production-ready application. A Todo List API is a perfect portfolio piece because it demonstrates CRUD operations, data management, validation, error handling, and clean code architecture - all skills employers look for in backend developers.

Key Concepts

  • Portfolio - Core technique for this lesson
  • Portfolio - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • Project - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • CRUD - Applied in this lesson's implementation

Project Requirements

  • Model Layer: Todo class with id, title, completed status, timestamp
  • Service Layer: TodoService with full CRUD operations
  • Validation: Prevent empty titles, handle invalid IDs
  • Search: Find todos by keyword
  • Filtering: Get completed vs pending todos
  • Statistics: Track total, completed, pending counts
  • Error Handling: Graceful error messages with Optional

Implementation Guide

Phase 1: Create Todo model with validation in constructor
Phase 2: Build TodoService with ArrayList storage
Phase 3: Implement CREATE (add todo)
Phase 4: Implement READ (get all, get by ID, search, filter)
Phase 5: Implement UPDATE (edit title, toggle completion)
Phase 6: Implement DELETE (remove by ID)
Phase 7: Add statistics and demo usage

Portfolio Value

This project demonstrates to employers:

  • RESTful API design patterns and CRUD operations
  • Clean architecture with separation of concerns (Model/Service)
  • Input validation and defensive programming
  • Java Streams for filtering and searching
  • Optional for null-safe programming
  • Professional code structure and documentation

Next Steps & Enhancements

File Persistence: Save/load todos from JSON file using Jackson or Gson
Spring Boot REST API: Add @RestController with proper endpoints
Database: Replace ArrayList with JPA/Hibernate and PostgreSQL
Authentication: Add user accounts with JWT tokens
Testing: Write JUnit tests for all CRUD operations
Frontend: Build React/Vue interface
Deployment: Deploy to Heroku, Railway, or AWS

Best Practices

  • Use proper HTTP status codes (200 OK, 201 Created, 404 Not Found, 400 Bad Request)
  • Implement input validation before processing requests
  • Use DTOs (Data Transfer Objects) to separate API models from domain models
  • Add pagination for list endpoints to handle large datasets
  • Include timestamps (createdAt, updatedAt) for all resources
  • Implement proper error responses with meaningful messages

Common Pitfalls

  • Not validating input - always check for null/empty values
  • Returning direct references to internal list (breaks encapsulation)
  • Poor error handling - use Optional, throw meaningful exceptions
  • Missing edge cases - test with empty list, invalid IDs, duplicate operations
  • No timestamps - production apps always track creation/modification times

Interview Talking Points

When discussing this project in interviews, say: 'I built a full CRUD Todo API demonstrating RESTful design principles. I implemented proper validation with defensive programming, used Java Streams for filtering, and Optional for null safety. The architecture separates concerns with distinct Model and Service layers, following clean code principles. I can easily extend this with Spring Boot REST endpoints, database persistence, and user authentication.'

Deployment Guide

Step 1: Push to GitHub with detailed README
Step 2: Add screenshots and demo
Step 3: Deploy to cloud (Heroku, Railway, or AWS)
Step 4: Add to portfolio and resume
Step 5: Write blog post about building it

lessons.tutorial:
Key Concepts

  • Portfolio - Build a complete blog platform with user authentication, post management, and comments. Demonstrates security, session m
  • Portfolio usage demonstrated through practical examples
  • Project usage demonstrated through practical examples

Overview

This advanced portfolio project demonstrates user authentication, authorization, and multi-user data management. A blog platform showcases security best practices, session handling, and access control - essential skills for any backend developer role.

Project Requirements

  • User registration and login with password hashing
  • Secure password storage (SHA-256 hashing)
  • Blog post CRUD operations
  • Authorization checks (users can only edit/delete their own posts)
  • Timestamp tracking for posts
  • Multi-user support with user isolation

Implementation Guide

Step 1: Create User model with secure password hashing
Step 2: Build AuthService for registration and login
Step 3: Create BlogPost model with author tracking
Step 4: Implement BlogService with CRUD operations
Step 5: Add authorization checks before update/delete
Step 6: Test multi-user scenarios and security

Portfolio Value

This project demonstrates to employers:

  • Security-first approach with password hashing
  • Authorization and access control implementation
  • Multi-user application architecture
  • Clean separation between auth and business logic
  • Defensive programming with Optional and validation

Enhancements

Comments: Add Comment model and nested comment support
Tags: Categorize posts with tags and filtering
Likes: Add like/unlike functionality
JWT: Replace basic auth with JSON Web Tokens
Database: Persist data with JPA/Hibernate
Frontend: Build React/Vue interface with rich text editor

Common Pitfalls

  • Storing passwords in plain text - ALWAYS hash passwords
  • Not checking authorization - verify user owns resource before modifying
  • Using weak hashing (MD5) - use SHA-256 or bcrypt
  • Missing input validation on username/password
  • Not handling concurrent modifications properly

Interview Talking Points

I built a multi-user blog platform with secure authentication using SHA-256 password hashing. I implemented proper authorization checks to ensure users can only modify their own content. The architecture separates authentication logic from business logic, making it easy to extend with features like comments, tags, and JWT token-based auth. This demonstrates my understanding of security best practices and multi-user application design.

Deployment Guide

GitHub: Push with detailed README and screenshots
Testing: Write unit tests for all components
Deploy: Use Heroku, Railway, or AWS for hosting
Portfolio: Add to your portfolio site with live demo link
Blog: Write technical blog post about building it

lessons.tutorial:
Overview

Build a complete e-commerce shopping cart system handling product selection, quantity management, discount codes, and checkout. This demonstrates essential business logic skills required for backend and full-stack roles at e-commerce companies.

Key Concepts

  • Portfolio - Core technique for this lesson
  • Portfolio - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • Project - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • E-Commerce - Applied in this lesson's implementation

Requirements

  • Product catalog with id, name, price, and category
  • Shopping cart with add, remove, and update quantity operations
  • Discount code system (percentage and fixed-amount)
  • Minimum purchase requirements for discounts
  • Price calculations with subtotal, discount, and total
  • Checkout process that completes the order

Implementation Guide

Start with Product and CartItem value objects. Build ShoppingCart using HashMap for O(1) product lookups. Implement discount validation to check minimum purchase requirements. Use Java Streams for calculating totals efficiently. The checkout process should display final summary and clear the cart.

Portfolio Value

This project showcases your ability to model real-world business logic with proper data structures, implement discount systems with business rules, handle money calculations, and design extensible cart operations. Perfect for e-commerce and retail company interviews.

Best Practices

  • Use BigDecimal for money calculations to avoid floating-point errors
  • Implement atomic operations for cart updates to prevent race conditions
  • Validate discount codes server-side (never trust client)
  • Set cart expiration (TTL) to free up memory from abandoned carts
  • Log all cart operations for analytics and fraud detection
  • Use database transactions for checkout to ensure consistency

Common Pitfalls

  • Floating-point errors with money - use BigDecimal in production
  • Not validating quantities (negative or zero)
  • Forgetting to check minimum purchase for discounts
  • Allowing discount to exceed subtotal amount
  • Not handling concurrent cart modifications

Interview Points

Be prepared to discuss: (1) How you'd scale to millions of users (Redis for carts, database for products), (2) Handling concurrent checkouts (optimistic locking), (3) Why HashMap over ArrayList (O(1) vs O(n) lookups), (4) How to prevent coupon abuse, (5) Database schema design for products and orders.

Next Steps

Enhance with: (1) Inventory management to prevent overselling, (2) Multiple discount codes with stacking rules, (3) Tax calculation by region, (4) Shipping cost calculation, (5) Order history tracking, (6) Save cart to database for persistence, (7) Build REST API endpoints.

lessons.tutorial:
Overview

Build a weather dashboard that integrates with external APIs, implements intelligent caching to reduce costs and improve performance, handles rate limiting, and displays formatted weather data. Critical skills for backend and full-stack roles.

Key Concepts

  • Portfolio - Core technique for this lesson
  • Portfolio - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • Project - Applied in this lesson's implementation
  • API Integration - Applied in this lesson's implementation

Requirements

  • Fetch weather data from external API (temperature, conditions, humidity)
  • Implement caching with configurable TTL (time-to-live)
  • Cache-first strategy to minimize API calls
  • Handle API errors gracefully (invalid cities, network failures)
  • Display formatted weather information
  • Support multiple cities with separate cache entries

Implementation Guide

Create WeatherData value objects to model API responses. Build a generic CacheManager with TTL support using HashMap and LocalDateTime-based expiration. Implement WeatherAPI interface to allow swapping real APIs with mock implementations for testing. The dashboard uses cache-first lookups: check cache, return if fresh, otherwise fetch from API and cache the result.

Portfolio Value

Proves you can integrate third-party APIs, implement production-ready caching (critical for reducing costs), and handle real-world constraints. Highlight how caching reduced API calls by 80%+, your TTL strategy, and defensive error handling. Shows both technical skills and business awareness.

Best Practices

  • Store API keys in environment variables, never hardcode them
  • Implement exponential backoff for retry logic on API failures
  • Use cache headers (Cache-Control, ETag) for HTTP caching
  • Set appropriate TTL based on data freshness requirements
  • Monitor cache hit rate - aim for 80%+ for significant cost savings
  • Implement circuit breaker pattern for external API calls

Common Pitfalls

  • Hardcoding API keys - use environment variables
  • Not handling API failures (network issues, timeouts)
  • Cache stampede - multiple requests hitting API simultaneously
  • Ignoring rate limits - can get API key banned
  • Memory leaks from unbounded cache growth
  • Timezone issues - always use UTC internally

Interview Points

Be ready to discuss: (1) Cache eviction policies (LRU, LFU, TTL), (2) Scaling for millions of users (Redis cluster), (3) Preventing cache stampede (probabilistic early expiration), (4) Cache-aside vs write-through patterns, (5) Monitoring cache hit rate and API health.

Next Steps

Enhance with: (1) Real weather API integration (OpenWeatherMap), (2) Redis for distributed caching, (3) Background cache warming for popular cities, (4) Weather alerts and notifications, (5) Historical weather tracking, (6) Geolocation support, (7) Build REST API endpoints.
